What's the fastest you've seen someone fired from a job? When I was 16, my dad told me I had to get a job or he'd kick me out of the house, and the only one I could find was at Build a bear. On my first day, I had to learn all the happy dances you do when a kid comes in, and after an hour of that, I was completely on my own. My manager left me there by myself, so I was really nervous. But I noticed a couple come in, and the woman was very pregnant. They didn't have a kid with them, but I still helped them pick out a bear along with a fancy heart that had a heartbeat. They still didn't look happy at all, so I tried to cheer her up and made the woman do the happy dance before I stuffed the bear for them. I could see they were both still really upset and not knowing what to do, I made the mistake of asking her if she was okay. She just looks up at me and told me they were there to make a bear for her baby to be buried with, because they had just found out their baby's heart wasn't beating anymore. I immediately stopped trying to make her dance and could barely keep it together as I made the bear for her. It took everything I had to keep a smile as I helped them pay But as soon as they left, I ran to the back and completely bawled my eyes out. My manager came back to the store a minute later, saw the huge line, and then found me crying in the back. I tried to explain what happened, but he just told me to get out because I was fired.

What did that one teacher do that you'll never forget? I was born with cerebral palsy and I believed my mom every time she told me it was cool to have it. I thought people were jealous of the way I walked because nobody else looked like me. That completely changed when I got to high school because they couldn't afford to send me to a special school anymore. I was the only black kid and I got bullied on the first day there. However, that wasn't anything compared to the principal's son. He knew he could get away with anything, so he constantly made fun of me for the way I moved and talked. And since every teacher was too afraid to punish him, he didn't stop. He kicked my canes out from under me a few times. And when my mom asked how I got the bruises from falling, I lied and said my shoes made me trip. Well, they saved up and bought me special walking shoes and it made me so happy the first day I wore them to school, that kid took them and threw them in the garbage. By the time I knew where they were, it was too late. And the only person who saw what happened was our math teacher. This guy hated our principal and hated his son even more. He knew what he did and in that moment didn't care about what was going to happen. He took that kid. Into his classroom and yelled so loud, everyone in the school heard it. The kid left the room crying and went straight to his dad. A week later, he lost his job and could never teach again. But the day he was clearing his stuff out of his room, he gave me a box. It was another pair of the shoes he had bought for me, and I still have them 30 years later.

People who've been in a coma, what shocked you the most when you woke up? When my daughter was 5, she begged me to put up Christmas lights for an entire day. She was literally crying because I was leaving for a work trip the next day and she told me Santa wouldn't come if our house wasn't decorated. It was really icy and snowing that day, but my wife told me to just do it. So I told her fine. I got the ladder and climbed up and my daughter passed me the lights and the colors she wanted. Right before we were almost finished, the slipped out from underneath me. I fell and hit my head on the concrete hard and remember the sound of her screaming. I didn't wake up until I was in the hospital later that day and felt the worst pain in my neck and back. I tried to feel for the bandages on my head, but strangely I didn't feel anything. I was really confused but barely managed to sit up and noticed I couldn't move my legs. I looked up and saw a nurse walk in the room and she looked really surprised. Five more people came in and all started asking me questions. I was really worried because I still couldn't move my feet no matter how hard I tried. I didn't know what was going on until an hour later when my wife finally got there. I was so happy. To see and didn't think anything about her. In tears, I asked who the girl she was with was because she was also crying. And when she walked closer, I made the most shocking realization of my life. This 13 year old was my daughter. And they broke the news. I was in a coma for almost nine years. I realized I had missed her entire childhood. I was paralyzed. My wife had remarried. But what hurt the most was when I went home to our house and I looked up at our roof. I broke down because those lights were still up.

My kids didn't know what Christmas was, and it destroyed me. Right after I got married to my wife, we were expecting our first daughter. We picked out a name for her. But a month before she was supposed to be born, I got the worst phone call of my entire life. That night, I lost them both. After five years, I finally gained the courage to try again. And when I heard about two kids who came from an abuse, abusive family at the adoption center, I filled out an application. They both lived in a van with their mom for years. And watching how excited both of them got when they finally got to have a warm bath and wear new clothes for the first time broke my heart. But here's what surprised me the most. Their mom treated them so horribly that when I asked them what they wanted for Christmas, they didn't know what I was talking about. They had never heard of Santa Claus. They didn't believe a man was actually gonna come bring them presents. When I told them on Christmas Eve, I thought, they kept running over to the window to look for him. I told them he wasn't coming until they were sleeping, but they said they were looking for the police to come since they always came to get them on Christmas Eve. I wasn't gonna let them see me crying after that. But the next morning I woke up to Both of them laughing because they saw the footprints I left on the carpet and the milk and cookies were gone. They didn't even care about the presents. They just kept saying, he's real, he's real.

My daughter broke her neck and was paralyzed. But today, a miracle happened. A year ago, when our daughter was three, we literally couldn't get her to stop moving. We took her to dance lessons every week, but one day on the way home, I remember seeing her sleeping in the back of the truck next to her brother. We were almost there when somebody turned left without enough time and hit us. My husband and I were completely unharmed, but they hit the door. She was sitting right next to you, and she had broken her neck. We sat at the hospital for two days before she got out of surgery and found out she was alive. Her spinal cord had been damaged, but she was stable. She was 3 years old, and she wasn't ever going to walk again. I didn't even know how to explain it to her and have barely seen her smile since. She cried when she watched her brother go on the swings while she couldn't, and constantly got stared at by other kids her age. I've caught my husband crying in the garage at night, thinking it was his fault. I thought he just wanted to be alone, but it turns out he was actually planning something. Yesterday was her birthday, and the gift she opened wasn't anything like what she was expecting. Instead, I found out what he had spent months designing. And since the accident, that day was the first time I've seen her laugh and smile since then, and for a little while she got to feel normal again.

I gave a girl the worst news of her life but she cried happy tears. I'm the head doctor of the emergency room and on the fourth of July we got a heads up that a ten year old girl had been badly injured. She was getting to the hospital in an ambulance and when I saw her I knew what it was. She had been hit in the face by a firework and it suffered severe damage to her eyes and nose. She was immediately put into surgery but we couldn't do anything. He was alive but had lost her sight completely. I gave the news to her parents and little brother and they both broke down. She was a star athlete so they were so upset they had to step out and left me to watch their little boy. He looked only three or four and just sat there. I couldn't find a nurse to watch him so I talked to him for a few minutes. He told me he was gonna try and make it better. And while I checked the girls vitals he ran and away. I was only looking away for 30 seconds and the boy was gone. I ran out of the room but he wasn't anywhere in sight. I was panicking because I just had to watch him for a few minutes and couldn't find him now. I called security and they told me where they had him. I went down to the Organ donation office. And there he was. Apparently, he was asking the girls at the front desk to give his sister one of his eyes because she lost hers and he didn't need both of his. It was so wholesome. And after the girl found out, she'd never see again. That at least made her smile.

I accidentally burned my house down, and it made me a millionaire. The day after my boyfriend and I bought our first house, I got a knock on the door right after we just finished moving in. I was in the middle of making dinner when I opened it, and a two police officers shining their flashlights at me. They asked what my name was, and when I told them, I could tell something was wrong. They asked my birthday, and as soon as I told them, they looked at each other. Then they told me to put my hands behind my back. I thought it was a joke, but they started yelling at me to do it without any explanation. They arrested me and took me to jail, and I was in literal tears the entire way. I tried to tell them I left the oven on, but they didn't believe me. They weren't telling me anything, and I had to spend the entire night in a cell. When they finally let me use the phone, I called my boyfriend. I was still bawling, and he didn't answer. I was cold, scared, and had no idea what was going on. Eventually, in the morning, they let me out, and when I finally got my phone back, I had so many notifications. My whole family was calling me because I had disappeared. And since the oven was left on, my house caught on fire. But here's the craziest part. It Turned without. The police arrested me because a woman stole someone's car while their kids were in it and drove off with them. She also just happened to have the exact same first, last name, and birthday as me. We lost our brand new house, but after I finished suing the police department, I bought a much nicer one.

What teacher insulted you in your own language? My math teacher thought I didn't speak Spanish. Big mistake. I was born in California, but my parents came from Colombia. When they were teenagers, at home, we spoke Spanish every single day. My mom would cook while telling me stories about her childhood in Bogota. My dad would watch soccer games and yell at the TV in Spanish. But at school, I always spoke English. It just felt more natural with my friends. Miss Graham was new to our school district. She transferred from some rural area upstate where apparently nobody looked like me. From Day 1, she made comments about the diversity programs and how standards were dropping, but she said it quietly, thinking none of us understood. During my second week in her algebra class, I was presenting a group project about linear equations. I made a small error while explaining one of the steps. No big deal happens to everyone. But Miss Graham leaned over to the teaching assistant and whispered in Spanish, Otra parea suzhenten nuca es walsa. Another lazy one. Her people never try hard. I froze. Did this woman really just call me lazy in Spanish right in front of me? I kept my face neutral and pretended I didn't understand, but inside I was furious. The worst part was she had this smug smile like she'd gotten away with something clever. I went home that night and told my mom everything. My mom works. Two jobs, cleaning offices at night and doing alterations during the day. She doesn't take disrespect from anybody, especially not some teacher insulting her daughter. But instead of marching to the principal's office like I expected, she sat down at our kitchen table and started planning. Mihow, we're going to be smart about this, she said. Keep track of everything, she says. Write it down with dates and times. And whatever you do, don't let her know you speak Spanish. For the next two weeks, I played completely dumb in math class. Miss Graham kept making comments in Spanish, thinking she was safe. She called me and other Hispanic students lazy, said our parents probably didn't care about education, even joke to the ta that we'd probably drop out anyway. I documented everything in a notebook word for word. The parent teacher conferences were scheduled for a Thursday evening. My mom took off work early, which was a big deal because she needed every hour. We walked into that classroom together and Miss Graham immediately got that condescending look teachers get when they think they're dealing with parents who don't speak English. Ah, we might need to call for a translator, Miss Graham said to the assistant principal who was also in the room for these meetings. She said it slowly and loudly.

What's the dumbest way you accidentally started a school trend? In 10th grade, I accidentally showed up to school in banana pajamas. Full set pants top, tiny cartoon bananas dancing everywhere. It wasn't a dare. I just overslept, grabbed what was on the floor, and ran out the door like my house was on fire. Thought I'd get clowned. Instead, some senior gave me a nod and said, respect the comfort, bro. By lunch, three kids had changed into Pjs. One guy showed up in a Spider Man onesie. A girl brought a weighted blanket and called it her emotional support cloak. The next day, chaos. Half the school was in pajama mode. Slippers, eye masks. Someone brought a neck pillow and took a nap during chemistry class. The principal tried to shut it down with a serious intercom announcement. This is school, not a sleepover. Please dress appropriately. So naturally, then, next day, someone came in a Snuggie. The media class made a fake trailer called revenge of the Pjs. It had slow motion shots of kids marching in unicorn onesies while the school anthem played on kazoo. By Friday, it was official. We had sparked the Pajama Rebellion. I didn't start it on purpose, but I became the face of it. Now, once a month, this school has cozy day. There's even a framed photo of me in banana PJs hanging in the student council room. Moral of the story sometimes you don't need a plan to become A legend. You just need to sleep through your alarm.

Have you ever replaced a substitute teacher and just kicked out the real one? My cousin forgot her laptop at my place and begged me to drop it off at Lincoln High. I walk into the office like a normal person and say, I'm here for Miss Taylor. The secretary looks panicked and goes, you're the sub, right, for room 2:00 o four. Before I can say anything, she slaps a badge on me that says Mister J, Substitute teacher, and shoves a clipboard in my hands. Next thing I know, I'm standing in front of 30 high school sophomores. A kid in the front goes, you the guy? I say, I'm whoever you need me to be. They go absolutely silent. I panic and blurt, alright, class today, we're learning zombie apocalypse survival. Suddenly, everyone's in. They're building barricades out of desks. One kid uses a stapler like it's a grenade. A girl creates a barter system using gum. Then the real sub walks in frazzled, holding an ID badge in a Starbucks. One student screams, it's starting. Another yells, she's infected. Look at her eyes. Kid hurls an eraser like it's a smoke bomb. Real sub tries to explain, but a student calmly says, Mr J has it under control and hands her a tissue like it's a peace offering. She slowly backs out of the room. No one breaks character. By the end, the principal walks in, sees kids drawing escape routes on the whiteboard and just Nods, innovative. That night, I get an email, we'd like to bring you in next Thursday. Theme, alien invasion preparedness. I texted back, only if I get a whistle this time.
NA
NA
NA
NA

Have you ever met a celebrity who asked you, do you know who I am? And you said no. My daughter had one of these encounters and it worked out well. She was a psychiatric nurse working on the crisis team but hoping to be able to work in the perinatal area. Unfortunately, there was no perinatal service in that area. One day she happened to be in the office at the hospital when a man came in and said, look, my daughter needs an impatient mental health bed now. She said, you could be right, sir, but I have just had a patient admitted to the last available one. We'll do what we can until another becomes available. He said, do you know who I am? She said she had no idea. He told her he was a senior politician in the cabinet. I will not name him as he was a good constituency MP. She told him that if mental health services were not so underfunded, she probably could have helped his daughter faster. She said, this is the sharp end of the funding decisions you make in cabinet and gave him the phone number of the local private clinic. He went away clearly annoyed, but a few weeks later she was owned by the head of mental health for her county and was told that more money had been released to set up a perinatal service and they wanted her to set it up and run it. Which she did. I don't think it was a coincidence that the money suddenly became available. Whether or not, he said, and I want that bulshy woman who cared enough about her patients to take me to task to run it, we don't know. This was some years ago now, and I admire him for doing something about it.

My siblings refused to let me come to their weddings, so I returned the favour. I have four significantly older siblings. All of them are now married. I was not invited to any of their weddings because each of them had a child free wedding. I, of course, thought I'd be the only exception as I am their sibling. But no. My oldest sibling first had a child free wedding and then the others decided to follow. When my oldest brother got married, I was 10 years old, so sure, I kind of understood why they didn't invite me, but I was still extremely upset. My oldest brother got married to a woman I really love and I couldn't even be there to witness it. The other brother got married when I was 12 years old. Yet again I wasn't invited. I still sort of understood, but when I was 12 years old, I was a very well behaved child and at the same time, his sibling. My sister got married when I was 15 years old. At first she didn't want a child free wedding, but all of the family members convinced her because OMG, it's so refreshing to be in a wedding where children don't bring havoc. So she decided to cut out everyone who was under 16 years old. When I asked if I could be an exception, since I was 15 at the time and her sister, she said no with a very serious tone. If We make an exception for you. What about other children? It's not fair! I got upset and screamed that it wasn't fair not to participate in any of my siblings weddings. My parents got upset with me and grounded me for six months. Lastly, my brother got married when I was 17 years old. I thought surely I'd be invited to this one. But at that point I didn't care. I knew it was going to be a child free wedding and somehow I wouldn't be invited as I guessed. I was right. I didn't ask or beg. My step cousin who just turned 18 just made the cut and I didn't. Well, as I said, I didn't care. I sent a quick congrats text and that was it. My parents got furious about why I didn't even congratulate them properly. I just ignored them and spent all the time in my room with my now soon to be husband. Since I'm getting married now, I decided none of them will be at my wedding since I wasn't allowed to be at theirs when they didn't get the invitation. You can now check if there's a part 2 by pressing share and more!
NA
NA

My birthday. Instead of waiting for my husband and son to come home to celebrate with me, I received a video from my husband's first girlfriend. In the video, my husband and my son were with her, and my son was hugging her, saying he wished she could be his mother. After seeing that, instead of calling him to confront him, I silently packed my suitcase and signed the divorce papers. It was unusual for my husband Dominic to come home at midnight and find the house completely dark. No matter what time it was, I always left a light on for him. That night, he handed our son Grayson over to the housekeeper and went straight to the master bedroom. I was sitting on the sofa with a carefully packed suitcase by my side and the I divorce agreement on the coffee table in front of me. Dominic frowned. Paisley, what is this? Another one of your dramatics? I didn't have the strength for his criticism. My voice came out calm and firm. I want a divorce! His face showed disbelief. Why? Because I forgot your birthday? It doesn't matter, I replied, pushing the divorce agreement toward him. Sign it. Let's end this. He flipped through the pages mockingly. You're leaving empty handed? Where will you go without me? A bitter laugh escaped my lips. He was so sure he had me trapped. Thinking I had no one in hierofel and nothing to hold on to, I pushed the Papers even closer. Sign it. Don't waste time. For a moment he hesitated, then his voice hardened. Fine. Divorce it is. But Sonny's custody is not negotiable. You won't get him. Suddenly Grayson appeared, looking at me with tears streaming down his cheeks. I'm staying with dad. I don't want to go with you. You're a horrible mother, a witch! That's enough, Grayson! Dominic snapped. But Grayson's rage didn't subside. If you hadn't gotten in the way of dad and Marissa, she'd be my mom now. I cut the tension with that same cold voice. I don't care, Grayson. I don't care about anything. I just want the divorce. That word left Dominic in silence. He clenched his jaw and his eyes darkened with frustration. Are you sure about this? I tossed the pen onto the table. Sign it. Let's end this. Dominic's frustration gave way to a flicker of doubt. Before he could sign, I grabbed my copy, took my suitcase, and headed for the door. Tomorrow at 9 a m. Sharp at City hall. Don't be late, I said without hesitation. Just as I was about to walk out, Dominic grabbed my wrist tightly. Let go! I said coldly. He sneered. In such a rush to leave? You already have a lover. I looked him straight in the eyes. If you don't want to wait for part 2, you can watch the full story on my YouTube channel. Just click on share and then more and then click On the YouTube link here in my profile or search for the Flag Stories Reddit channel on YouTube.
NA

When is that one time that you had to turn to the dark side? One day my daughter came back from school and ran into my arms like she was scared. I could feel her shaking so I took her inside and made some French toast, which was her favorite food. I thought she just had a really bad day and missed being at home. But I couldn't have been more wrong. Once she calmed down, she told me, Mommy, something happened today and I think I'm supposed to tell you about it. An uneasy knot formed itself in my heart when she told me that the school counselor had called her into his office for a special game. He handed my daughter a stuffed unicorn and told her that this new game was very popular with the children, which made my daughter excited and eager to learn. Then the counselor made her point the unicorn between his legs and push on it repeatedly. My daughter told me how he made weird faces at times and then closed his eyes and leaned back. Towards the end, I was so horrified and felt a wave of nausea rush through my body so I had to go to the bathroom and throw up. What kind of sick person would make a 7 year old girl do this kind of thing? Not to mention he worked at a school and it was me who willfully sent my daughter near his vicinity. Bouncing between blaming myself and wanting to burn the entire world. My husband was no longer with us, so it was up to me to stand up for my daughter. I don't know what made me approach the school administration before the police, but that's exactly what I did. And the school administration laughed at me, saying that my daughter was clearly playing a prank. They said they had heard other students make similar jokes about the school counselor and said that parents should teach their kids not to lie. By the time I made it to the police station, the school had already called them and explained the situation. They thought I was a crazy mother who was trying to give merit to my daughter's filthy lie. I had looked straight into my daughter's eyes when she told me the story, so I knew she was telling the truth. But no one wanted to believe me. And I felt like I was in a nightmare. This is when I remembered something important and ran back home to open my jewelry safe. Inside there was a note that I hadn't looked at for a long time. You see, although I was currently a doctor, I had been a very inexperienced nurse at one point. And one time a very stern looking man with a lot of face tattoos walked into our hospital with a bullet wound. No other nurse wanted to treat him since he looks so scary. So they Sent me. I convinced myself that everyone deserves treatment and cleaned his wounds with the utmost concentration. I even engaged him in conversation and joked about how he should stay away from bullets in the future. When it was all over, the guy thanked me and handed me a note with his phone number on it. He said, if you ever need someone taken care of, I won't ask for any payment. I typed in that phone number and to my surprise, it actually connected. I told him who I was and he said, I remember you. If you don't want to wait for part 2, you can watch the full story on my YouTube channel. Just click on share and then more and then click on the YouTube link here in my profile or search for the Flag Stories Reddit channel on YouTube.

Made you finally stand up to your parents. My mom kept borrowing money from my savings account without asking. Started small when I was 15, 20 here, 50 there. Always promised, I'll pay you back next week, sweetheart. I was saving for my first car, working weekends at Scoops Ice Cream downtown. The job absolutely sucked. Sticky floors covered in melted ice cream, screaming kids having sugar meltdowns and my chain smoking manager, Derek, who reeked of cigarettes. After two grueling years of scooping rocky road and mopping chocolate spills every night, I'd saved almost $3,000. Then I checked my balance at the ATM. 8, 47, 32, my heart stopped. I drove straight home, found mom making fancy curried coffee with expensive pods she claimed we couldn't afford. Mom, where's my money? She didn't look. Oh, honey, I needed it for groceries. Things are tight since the divorce. You'll get it back. But groceries don't cost $2,000. I started watching her spending. New coach purse from the outlet mall, weekly salon appointments for highlights, fancy dinners with club friends every Friday, all while telling me we had to tighten our belts and couldn't afford name brand cereal I liked. I felt sick. This was my money from my job dealing with brain freeze headaches in that walk in freezer every single night. When I confronted her again, she got defensive. I'm your mother, Jessica. I've spent way more than 3,000 raising you over 17 years. Consider this paying me back. For all those diapers and formula. That comment made my blood boil. That's when I knew I had to be smart about this. During lunch break, I went to First National Bank and asked to speak with someone about my account to tell her. Margaret pulled up my statements, her face changing as she scrolled through months of transactions. Your mom's been withdrawing money almost weekly for six months, I whispered. Since you're a minor, this is technically a joint account, so it's legal. But you can open your own when you turn 18 next month. She leaned closer. Until then, you could withdraw everything and keep it somewhere safe. That night, I didn't confront mom. Instead, I went back the next day and withdrew every penny except $1, opened a new account at Community Credit Union across town that only I could access. For three days, I acted completely normal, went to work, came home, did chemistry homework, watch Netflix with mom like nothing had changed. She had no idea I'd moved my entire life savings. Then Friday night, I heard her giggling on the phone with her friend Linda, planning their weekly book club dinner at that expensive steakhouse downtown. Don't worry about splitting the chat, she laughed. I'll just grab some cash from Jessica's account tomorrow morning. She never checks it anyway. Twenty minutes later, she knocked on my door wearing silk pajamas. Hey, sweetie, I'm running to the ATM before book club. Need anything from CVS? I smiled innocently. No.

Girlfriend pointed an unloaded gun in my face. It happened last Tuesday around nine PM. I was at my girlfriend Emma's apartment watching Netflix when she randomly got up and went to her bedroom. I thought she was just going to the bathroom or something, but then she came back holding her dad's old hunting rifle. The thing looked ancient but well maintained. Check this out, she said, pointing it directly at my forehead from maybe three feet away. My dad taught me how to use this when I was 12. I literally froze. Like, completely stopped breathing for a second. The barrel was staring me right in the face, and all I could think was how massive it looked from that angle. My heart started pounding so hard I could hear it in my ears. Emma, what the hell are you doing? I managed to say, trying not to move. She laughed like it was the funniest thing ever. Relax, it's not loaded. See? She pulled the trigger and nothing happened except for a loud click. But hearing that click while looking down the barrel made my stomach drop into my shoes. Are you insane? You never point a gun at someone, loaded or not. I was practically yelling at this point. She rolled her eyes. God, you're such a baby. It's empty. I checked. My dad always kept the ammo locked up separately anyway. But here's the thing. I grew up around guns, too. My uncle took me Hunting every fall since I was 10, and the first rule he drilled into my head was, you never, ever point a firearm at anything you don't intend to destroy. Look, loaded or unloaded? Doesn't matter. It's like gun safety 1:01. Emma, this isn't a joke. That's literally the most dangerous thing you can do with a gun. I said, standing up slowly with my hands visible. Even if you think it's empty. She was still holding it casually, like it was a toy or something. You're being dramatic. I've handled this gun a million times. That's when I decided to prove my point. I asked her to hand me the rifle, and she did. Still thinking I was overreacting, I pointed it toward the ground. And. Work.

To talk to your parents anymore. My parents discovered I wasn't their biological child when I was 16, not through some dramatic DNA test, through my little sister's science project. She was doing genetics homework, mapping out eye colours and couldn't make our family tree work. Brown eyes plus brown eyes can't make blue eyes, he said, pointing at me. Mom went white. Dad started stuttering about recessive genes. That night I heard them screaming through the walls. Mom admitted she'd had an affair 17 years ago. Dad wasn't my father. The man who raised me, taught me to ride a bike, helped with homework for 16 years, suddenly looked at me like I was a stranger. The change was immediate and brutal. Dad stopped coming to my baseball games. I tried talking to him. He'd respond with one word answers or just leave the room. Mom kept insisting nothing had changed, but she'd flinch whenever dad was cold to me. Then came the comparisons. Every family dinner became a catalog of how my sister and I were different. Look how naturally athletic Sophie is, dad would say, watching her throw a ball. She gets that from me. The implication hung in the air like poison. They started treating me like a house guest. My curfew got earlier while my sister stayed the same. My allowance got cut because money is tight. But Sophie got new clothes whenever she asked. When I brought it up, mom said I was being Dramatic. The worst part was watching them rewrite history. Photos of me got moved to the back of albums. My baby pictures disappeared from the mantle. Dad started telling stories about Sophie's milestones while pretending mine never happened. It was like they were erasing 16 years. My breaking point came during Christmas. Extended family was over and Uncle Mike asked about my college plans. Dad said, well, he's not really academic like Sophie. Different genetics, you know, he said genetics like it was a dirty word. That's when it clicked. They didn't just learn I wasn't blood related. They decided I wasn't family. So I made a choice that destroyed them. I found my biological father. His name was John Sins. He lived three states away, had no idea I existed. When I called him, he cried, actually cried. Said he'd wondered about my mom for years, hoped she was happy. Two weeks later, John drove 400 miles to meet me. He brought photo albums of his family, told me about my half brother who played baseball like me, showed me pictures of my real grandmother who had died the year before. But here's what broke my parents. John didn't just accept me, he celebrated me. Within a month, he'd driven back twice more. He came to my games, met my friends, took me car shopping. For my 17th birthday, my parents watched this man give me everything they'd taken away. Dad became obsessed, calling John a stranger, trying to Steal his son. Mom begged me to stop seeing him, said it was destroying our family. I told them they'd already destroyed it. The night they decided biology mattered more than 16 years of love, the final blow came at graduation. Both my family showed up. John sat in the front row cheering.

My daughter came home crying every day from school because her best friend started ignoring her after getting a new iPhone that my daughter couldn't afford. Emma had been best friends with Zoe since second grade. They did everything together. Walked to school, ate lunch at the same table, had sleepovers every weekend. My daughter would come home with stories about their inside jokes and secret handshakes. They were inseparable. But everything changed when Zoe got an iPhone 15 for her 13th birthday. Suddenly, Emma wasn't getting invited to hang out anymore. At lunch, Zoe would sit with the girls who had fancy phones, showing off her new camera and playing games. Emma couldn't join because she only had my old flip phone. I came home in tears three days straight. Mom, Zoe won't even look at me. She said I'm boring now because I can't text her or be in the group chat. It broke my heart watching my confident daughter shrink into herself. I worked two jobs just to keep us afloat after the divorce. There was no way I could afford a six hundred dollar phone for a 13 year old. But seeing Emma's face every day, knowing she was eating lunch alone while her former best friend posted Instagram stories with new friends, made me desperate. That's when I remembered something my grandmother taught me about friendship. She used to say, real friends don't need expensive things to connect. They need shared experiences and genuine care. For each other. I had an idea. Instead of trying to compete with technology, I would give Emma something Zoe's iPhone couldn't. Real adventure. I started planning surprise activities for Emma and whoever wanted to join. Many road trips to the beach, camping in our backyard, teaching her to bake my grandmother's secret cookie recipe. The first weekend, only Emma and I went hiking. But she seemed happier than she'd been in weeks. Taking photos with my old digital camera and collecting pretty rocks. She posted one blurry photo on her rarely used social media with the caption, adventures with Mom. Monday at school, three different girls asked Emma about her weekend. Turns out, while everyone else was stuck inside on their phones, Emma had stories to tell. Real stories about getting lost on the trail and finding a hidden waterfall. Within two weeks, Emma had new friends asking to join our weekend adventures. Girls who were tired of just staring at screens wanted to come camping, learn to bake, go on photo walks around town. The turning point came during our third weekend camping trip. We had four girls with us, roasting marshmallows and telling ghost stories. That's when Zoe showed up at our campsite with her mom. Emma's mom said we could stop by. Zoe said quietly, looking around at the fire. Intense. My mom thought it looked fun when she saw your photos. For a moment, nobody said anything. Then Emma smiled and handed Zoe a marshmallow.
NA

Nurses what's the funniest thing someone has said while high on anesthesia? So this middle aged dude named Tom comes in for routine knee surgery. Nothing fancy, just cleaning up some torn cartilage. He seemed pretty normal during pre op, just nervous like everyone else. Kept asking if we had any snacks because he'd been fasting since midnight. We told him the usual stuff about no eating before surgery, and he nodded along. The anesthesiologist starts his countdown, telling Tom to relax and count backwards from 10. Tom gets to about seven, when suddenly he sits bolt upright and shouts, don't touch the snack drawer! It's cursed! Everyone in the OR just froze. Doctor Williams, our anesthesiologist, looked confused. The surgeon stopped prepping. I mean, what do you even say to that? We thought maybe he was having some kind of panic attack or weird reaction to the meds, but Tom was already out, completely unconscious, breathing steady. Figured it was just random nonsense. You know, people say weird stuff when they're going under. So we continued with prep, positioning his leg, getting the instruments ready. About five minutes in, I lean over to grab some gauze from the bedside cabinet. That's when I accidentally knocked into this whole stack of snack packets sitting on the shelf. Chips, granola bars, those little cookies from the vending machine, candy bars, all of it went flying. It was like an explosion of junk food hitting the floor, bouncing everywhere, making this huge Mess. Tom's eyes snap open for just a second, still completely loopy, and he whispers, see? I told you it was cursed. Then his head drops back down. The entire surgical team just lost it. We're all trying not to laugh too loud while picking up Cheetos and Kit Kats off the sterile floor. Even Doctor Williams was cracking up behind his mask. But that was just the beginning. For the next 20 minutes, Tom kept mumbling these incredibly detailed warnings about everything in the room. He told us the stapler was plotting against the clipboard because it was jealous of how much paper it got to hold. The blood pressure cuff was apparently an undercover spy working for the hospital administration to steal our lunch money. The fourth bag kept smile smiling at the ceiling because it knew secrets about the night shift that we didn't want to hear. Every time one of us tried to reassure him that everything was fine, he'd contradict us with some new revelation. He insisted the surgical mask had a hidden agenda to steal pens from our pockets when we weren't looking. The heart monitor was supposedly gossiping about other patients in different rooms. The oxygen tank was planning a retirement party, but didn't want to invite the wheelchair because it had trust issues. At one point, Tom looked directly at Doctor Williams and said very seriously, your beard is whispering to the surgical lights about your weekend plans. You might want to Have a talk with it about privacy. Doctor Williams doesn't even have a beard. He's completely clean shaven. But Tom was so convinced, he kept giving him advice about beard maintenance and grooming products. The funniest part was when he started narrating what he thought. We were all thinking he'd point

video_description: My stepchildren said they answer only totheir biological parents. So l changed thelocks, cancelled every privilege in my name,and told their father pick up was tonight. Noone argued.#reddit #ask #story  #friends #awkwardtuesdayphonecall #seconddateupdate #radioshow  #louquitsonair #quit #badboss 1080P
voice_to_text: My stepchildren said they answer only to their biological parents. So I changed the locks, canceled every privilege in my name, and told their father pick up was tonight. No one argued. I'm Tom, 35, and I've been married to Lisa for 18 months. She has two kids from her first marriage. Marcus, 17, and Sophia, 15. Their biological father lives about 40 minutes away and sees them maybe twice a month when he feels like showing up. When Lisa and I got together, I genuinely wanted to be the stepdad I never had growing up. My own father walked out when I was 12, so I knew what it felt like to need a father figure. I thought being a good stepdad meant being the yes man. Always supportive, always generous, always understanding. New school clothes? Sure, no problem. Concert tickets for Sophia's favorite band? Of course. When Marcus wanted the latest gaming setup, I dropped 800 dollars without blinking. When he crashed my car last month after staying out past curfew, I didn't even make him pay the 500 dollar deductible. But respect, that was a completely different story. It started with small things. You're not our real dad became their go to response whenever I asked them to do basic household tasks. When I'd ask Marcus to take out the trash, he'd say, I only listen to actual parents. When Sophia left dishes piled in the sink for days, she'd shrug and say, my mom didn't tell Me to clean them. Lisa would have talks with them about respect. They'd apologize and behave for maybe a week. Then we'd be right back to the same pattern. The breaking point came Last Friday. I decided to leave work early to surprise Lisa with dinner plans for our anniversary weekend. I pulled into the driveway around three in the afternoon and immediately knew something was wrong. There were cars I didn't recognize parked on our street, and I could hear music blasting from inside the house. I walked through my front door to find about 20 teenagers having a full blown party in my living room. Red solo cups everywhere, the coffee table pushed against the wall. Kids I'd never seen before eating food from my kitchen. My house was completely trashed. Broken lamp, mysterious stains on my white couch, and the bottle scattered everywhere. Marcus was in the center of it all, acting like the king of the castle. When he saw me, he didn't even look embarrassed, just annoyed that I'd shown up. Party's over, I said loudly. Everyone out now! The music stopped. Kids started grabbing their stuff and heading for the door, but Marcus didn't move. Clean this mess up immediately, I told him once the house was empty. He actually laughed. You can't tell me what to do! You're not my father! This is my house! Marcus! My couch that's ruined! My lamp that's broken! No, Sophia interrupted, appearing from the kitchen. It's Mom's. House, too. We live here. We only take orders from real family, not from some guy mom married. That's when I noticed something that made my blood run cold. The door to my home office was wide open, and I always kept it locked. I walked over and immediately saw that my safe was open. My emergency cash envelope, the one where I've been saving money for Lisa's surprise birthday trip to Hawaii, was completely empty. 2000

video_description: On Christmas, my sister gave me apaternity test, so you rememberyou're not part of this family, whiledad laughed hysterically.#reddit #ask #story  #friends #awkwardtuesdayphonecall #seconddateupdate #radioshow  #louquitsonair #quit #badboss 1080P
voice_to_text: On Christmas, my sister gave me a paternity test. So you remember, you're not part of this family. While dad laughed hysterically. I'm 29. Always been the odd one out in the Peterson family. Different hair, different build, different everything. They joke about the mailman constantly. So when Sarah handed me that DNA kit with a smirk, in time to prove what we all know, I wasn't even surprised. Dad was cracking up, mom nodding like she'd been waiting years for this moment. Fine, I said, but let's make it interesting. How about we all take DNA tests? You know, for science. The room went quiet. Sarah laughed nervously. Why would we need to? Because I already took one six months ago, I said, pulling out my phone. And according to 23 and me, I have a half sister named Jessica. Been looking for her biological family. I showed them Jessica's profile. Same last name as Mom's Maiden name. Same distinctive birthmark mom has on her wrist. Jessica was born 9 months after Mom's business trip to Chicago in 1995. Remember that trip, mom? The one where you couldn't be reached for three days? Mom's face went white. Dad stopped laughing immediately. Oh, it gets better. I continued scrolling through my phone. Jessica wasn't the only surprise. I have three half siblings from Mom's various work conferences. I showed them photos. This is Michael from Denver, born in 1998. Ring any bells about that marketing seminar you attended? Alone. Sarah grabbed the phone. That's not possible. And here's little Emma from Portland. Born in 2,001. Funny how she has the same rare eye condition as Mom. Dad's face was turned red, but not from laughter anymore. Linda, what the hell is this? The best part. I pulled out a thick envelope from my jacket. I've been in contact with all three of them for months. They all want to meet their biological mother. In fact, they're driving here right now. Mom stood up shakily. You didn't. I did. Jessica should be here in about an hour. Michael's flying in from Denver tonight. Emma's parents are bringing her tomorrow morning for Christmas brunch. I looked at Sarah, who was still holding the DNA kit. So tell me again about not being part of this family. Because it looks like you're about to have a lot more family than you bargained for. Dad was staring at mom like he'd never seen her before. 26 years, Linda. Twenty six years of marriage, and you've been lying about three children. Actually, I said, checking my messages. Make that four. Just got a DNA match notification this morning. Apparently, there's a David from Miami who's also looking for answers. The doorbell rang. Through the window, I could see a young woman with mom's exact nose and chin standing on our porch holding a wrapped present. That'll be Jessica, I said, walking toward the door. I told her we were having a family reunion. Sarah finally found her voice. You planned this whole thing. You gave me six months to prepare. After I took that DNA test, I shrugged. Did you really think I'd just sit on information this explosive? I opened the door. Jessica, come in. Meet your biological family. Jessica walked in looking exactly like mom did in old photos. Hi, everyone.

I couldn't believe what I was hearing. After being homeless for two years, sleeping in parking lots, showering at truck stops, I finally saved enough to buy my own place. A small three bedroom house. They called it an eye sore and told me to figure it out myself. My brother Dan actually laughed, calling me a homeless bum while his wife took pictures to mock me on social media. Now here they were, all four of them plus Dan's pregnant wife, going up at my door unannounced. They didn't even have my address. I never gave it to them. They must have followed me from work or something. Equally creepy. The moment I opened the door, they pushed past me like they owned the place. My parents were walking through my house like real estate agents, pointing at rooms, measuring spaces with their eyes, discussing which kid would get which bedroom. His wife and kids had already made themselves comfortable on my couch, feet up on my coffee table, tracking MUD across my carpet. Look, this is simple, Dan said, not even looking me in the eye. You don't need all this space. We're moving in next weekend. Can live in that camper out back. Daniel has four kids and another on the way. You're being selfish, living in all this space alone. My dad nodded from the doorway. It's time you helped family instead of just thinking about yourself. We raised you better than this. The audacity was breathtaking. These were the same people who wouldn't let me park in their driveway when I was literally homeless. That I'm paying the mortgage on. So you can live here for free? We're not asking, Dan said, stepping closer like he was trying to intimidate me. We're telling you, family comes first. You owe us. After everything we've done for you. Everything you've done for me? I almost choked. You literally called me a homeless bum and refused to help when I was living in my truck. That was different. My mom snapped. You were irresponsible back then. Now you need to step up and do the right thing. Dan's wife finally spoke up. From my

voice_to_text: My kid's music teacher stole his song and gave it to another student. So I made sure everyone knew the truth. My son Ethan had been working on this piano piece for months. Every night after dinner, he'd sit at our crappy secondhand keyboard that I got from some garage sale for $50 and play this melody he wrote. He called it sky falling because he said it sounded like what falling from the sky would feel like. The kid was 10, but he had this ear for music that honestly blew my mind. He'd written the whole thing out by hand on music paper, every note perfectly placed. His handwriting was messy as hell, but the music was beautiful. Haunting, even. He recorded himself playing it on my phone, like 15 times until he got a version he was happy with. Then he submitted it for his school music project. Ethan was so proud of that song, he'd play it for anyone who'd listen. Our neighbours probably knew it by heart at that point. When he told me he was going to perform it at the spring recital, I marked my calendar and took the afternoon off work. Day of the recital came and I was sitting in the school auditorium with all the other parents. I looked at the program and saw Ethan listed as a backup performer. That was weird because he'd been practicing for weeks, but whatever. Maybe they had too many kids who wanted to Perform. Then the lights dimmed and this kid named Ryan walked onto the stage. He sat down at the piano and started playing. The first few notes hit me like a punch to the gut. It was sky falling. Ethan song. Note for note, exactly the same. I looked over at Ethan sitting with his class. His face went from confusion to this crushed expression that made my chest tight. He knew his song when he heard it, and he couldn't understand why someone else was playing it. Ryan finished and everyone clapped. The teacher, Mister Davies, walked to the microphone and said, that was a beautiful original composition by Ryan titled Sky Falling. Original Composition. My blood started boiling. After the recital ended, I found Mister Davies by the piano. Excuse me, I said, trying to keep my voice calm. My son Ethan wrote that song. Why was Ryan performing it? Mister Davies smiled this awkward, dismissive smile. Oh, Ethan's version needed too much polish. I gave it to Ryan because he's more technically advanced. Same idea, just cleaner execution. I stared at him. You used my kid's original composition without giving him credit? He shrugged like it was no big deal. It's for the school, not a competition. It's really not that deep. Not that deep? This man just told me stealing my son's work wasn't that deep. That night, I didn't sleep. Instead, I gathered everything. voice_to_text: My golden child brother stole and wrecked my truck, and my parents blamed me, so I got him arrested, and now they're begging me to save him. My brother William has always been the favorite. When we were kids, he broke my Nintendo, and somehow I got grounded for not putting it away safely when he failed math. It's because I didn't help him study enough. When he stole $20 from my birthday money, my parents said I shouldn't have left it where he could see it. The pattern never changed. William would mess up, and somehow it became my responsibility to fix it or prevent it from happening again. Last month, I finally saved enough from my restaurant job to buy a used pickup truck. I've been working doubles every weekend for 8 months, skipping hanging out with friends, eating ramen for dinner most nights. Nothing fancy, a 2009 Ford with 150 k miles and a few rust spots. But it was mine. The first thing that was actually legally completely mine. William immediately started asking to borrow it. Come on, bro, just for one night. I need to pick up this girl I'm talking to. I always said no, because he'd already crashed two of Dad's cars and somehow never faced any real consequences. Dad just kept buying him new ones while lecturing me about responsibility. The begging turned into guilt trips. You're being selfish became a daily phrase from my parents. Family shares with family. But I Held firm. That truck represented eight months of sacrifice, and I wasn't about to watch William destroy it like everything else. Friday night, I went to see a movie with my coworker, Megan. We've been planning it for weeks. First time I'd spent money on entertainment in months. When I came out of the theater around 11 p m, my truck was gone from the parking lot. I immediately knew it was William. I called him straight to voicemail, called my parents. They claimed they had no idea where he was and suggested maybe I'd parked somewhere else. Right, because I'd forget where I parked the truck I'd saved eight months to buy. I spent two hours walking around nearby streets, thinking maybe he just moved it as some stupid prank. Megan offered to drive me home, but I was too angry to think straight. Around 2 a m, I got a call from Mercy General Hospital. We have a William Walker here who was in an accident. He listed you as an emergency contact. My heart dropped. Despite everything, he was still my brother. I rushed to the hospital, expecting the worst. William was sitting up in bed with a few cuts and bruises, flirting with a nurse and acting like nothing happened. Oh, hey, bro. Funny story. That's when the doctor told me what really happened. William had been drag racing on Creek Road, the winding back road where three kids died last year doing the exact same Thing. He'd wrapped my truck around an oak tree, going at least 60 miles per hour. My truck was completely totaled. Eight months of work gone. But here's the part that broke me. My parents rushed into the hospital room and immediately started yelling at me. Why didn't

Dad left me at Grandpa's house when I was 11 because his new wife didn't want me around. I thought it was the worst thing ever. But Grandpa taught me everything about farming and business. Grandpa wasn't just some old farmer. He owned 500 acres of prime agricultural land worth millions. When dad was growing up, Grandpa was an alcoholic who barely kept the farm running. But by the time I arrived, he'd gotten sober and turned everything around. For seven years, it was just me and Grandpa. He taught me how to work cattle, manage crops, handle finances and run a business. We'd wake up at 5:00am every day, work until sunset, then he'd help me with homework. He never missed a single school event. When he died, he left me everything. Not just the land, the house, the equipment, the bank accounts, everything. I was 18 and suddenly owned more than most people see in a lifetime. Dad didn't even come to the funeral. Didn't call to check on me. Nothing. I spent the next 15 years building Grandpa's legacy. I turned the ranch into a successful agritourism operation. City families come stay for weeks, learning farm life. I also run a farmers market, sell organic beef and lease land to other farmers. Last year I cleared 800,000 dollar profit. Dad never Called once in 15 years. Not on my birthday, not on holidays, nothing. I sent him a graduation invitation when I finished my agriculture degree. He didn't show. When I got married three years ago, I didn't even bother inviting him. Then last week, out of nowhere, dad shows up at my door. Not to apologize, not to reconnect. He wanted to talk business. Turns out his precious daughter, my half sister, who I've met exactly twice, is struggling financially. Her husband lost his job, they're behind on their mortgage and she needs a fresh start. Dad figured I could just hand over some land and give her a management position. Family sticks together, he says with a straight face. The audacity was unbelievable. This man who abandoned his eleven year old son was lecturing me about family loyalty. I told him I'd think about it, hoping he'd get the hint and leave. Instead, he started texting me multiple times, daily. Detailed messages about which parcels of land would be perfect for his daughter. Suggestions about what roles she could fill in my business. Even ideas about where she and her husband could build a house. The messages got more demanding each day. She deserves this opportunity. Grandpa would have wanted this. You owe the family. It was like he thought my property was some kind of family commune he could just redistribute. After a week of constant harassment, I'd had enough. I called my friend Samuel, who's a local Police officer and asked him how to get a trespass order. Thirty minutes later, I walked out of the station with legal paperwork in hand. Then I asked another close friend, Peter, to take a road trip with me. I need backup for a family reunion. I told him. He didn't ask questions, just grabbed his keys. It took us 10 hours to drive to Dad's house. I needed that time to clear my head and plan exactly what I was going to say. Peter kept offering to drive, but I needed something to do with my hands while I processed everything. We pulled up to Dad's mom

Paid for with my own sweat and overtime hours. Two years ago, I married Amanda, who seemed responsible and down to earth as a mental hygienist. I kept the house in my name to protect my assets. After seeing my brother's messy divorce about six months ago, things changed. Amanda became critical of everything, started spending more time at the gym, bought new clothes, and often had late yoga classes. I wasn't born yesterday. The signs were all there, but I figured I'd let it play out and see what she was really up to. Last Tuesday, while working downtown, I got a text from Amanda. I'm done with this marriage. Change the locks. Brad's moving in this weekend. My lawyer will contact you about dividing assets. Add her personal trainer from the fancy gym across town. The pieces clicked into place immediately. I'm standing there in my work boots, tool belt around my waist, reading this message twice to make sure I understood it correctly. This woman really thought she could just me out of my own house and move her Boyfriend in like, some kind of real estate hostile takeover. My coworker Mike saw my face and asked what was wrong. I showed him the text, and he just started laughing. Dude, she knows you actually own that place, right? That's when it hit me. Amanda had always acted like we owned the house together, but she'd never seen the deed, never been involved in property taxes, never dealt with homeowners insurance. In her mind, marriage automatically meant shared ownership of everything. I called my buddy Steve, who's a real estate agent. Steve, remember how you said my house would sell fast in this market? How fast are we talking, Mark? With the location and condition, I could have buyers lined up by tomorrow. If you're serious. Dead serious. I need a cash buyer who can close in two weeks, max. What's the rush? Let's just say I'm dealing with some unwanted house guests. By Wednesday morning, Steve had three cash offers above asking price. I picked the highest one with the fastest closing date, exactly 12 days away. Thursday morning, I drove by the house to see Brad's lifted truck in my driveway, his motorcycle in my garage. The audacity was breathtaking. This guy was already making himself at home, probably thinking he'd hit the Jackpot with his new living situation. I parked across the street and called Amanda. She answered on the first ring, probably expecting me to beg to come home. Amanda, I hope you and Brad Are comfortable because you've got 11 days to enjoy the place. What are you talking about? I sold the house. Cash buyer closing next Friday. You'll need to be out by then. The silence stretched so long, I thought the call had dropped. Then she exploded. You can't sell our house without my permission. I'll sue you. Brad gave up his apartment lease. Actually, I can sell my house whenever I want. It's called property ownership. Maybe Brad should have checked the deed before giving up his lease. This is insane. Where are we supposed to go? Amanda, that became not my problem the second you changed my locks.

I told my sister in law, no one cares that she's pregnant. My cousin Rachel just buried her husband and two kids last week. Car accident took them all at once. She's left with just her five year old daughter, Emma. And honestly, watching them at the funeral was the most heartbreaking thing I've ever seen in my life. So my brother Jake and his wife Kelly show up to our house that morning. Before we head to the church, first thing Kelly does is announce she's pregnant. We're all getting ready for a funeral, and she's like, guess what, everyone, we have news. My mom congratulated her, but told her to keep it quiet for today out of respect. Did Kelly listen? Of course not. The second we get to the church, Kelly starts making these loud gagging noises and rubbing her completely flat stomach. Every time someone looked at her, she'd go, oh, sorry, morning sickness, I'm pregnant. You know, she kept saying stuff like, as a mom, I just can't imagine what Rachel's going through, which was ridiculous because Kelly doesn't have any kids yet. At the cemetery, she literally asked Rachel's sister to give up her seat so the pregnant lady could rest her feet. She'd been standing for like 10 minutes total. I was getting so annoyed, but I kept my mouth shut because it's a funeral. After the service, we went back to my aunt's house. Kelly kept making everything about herself. Someone would Mention how hard this must be for Rachel. And Kelly would jump in with, oh, I know. Now that I'm pregnant, I understand maternal instincts so much better. When people were talking about the babies who died, Kelly would rub her stomach and talk about how excited she was to be a mom. The bathroom thing was what really got me. Every time Kelly needed to use the bathroom, she'd announce, pregnant lady coming through or, baby on board needs to pee there. We're like 30 people there grieving, and she's treating it like her personal pregnancy announcement party. But then she crossed the line. Rachel was sitting quietly in the corner with Emma, both of them just completely destroyed. Kelly walks right up to them, sticks out her flat belly, and says, me and Jake just found out I'm pregnant. And honestly, we're beside ourselves thinking about how something like this could happen to us, too. Rachel completely broke down, started sobbing so hard she could barely breathe. Emma got scared and started crying, too. Everyone in the room just stopped and stared. That's when I lost it. I stood up and said, loud enough for everyone to hear, Kelly, no one gives a damn that you're pregnant. Look around you. This is a funeral for two babies and their father. You took that pregnancy test four days ago, and you're acting like you're the first woman to ever get pregnant. Just leave. Kelly started crying and ran out. Jake followed her, but not before calling me a fat, bitter witch in front of everyone. My aunt had to comfort Rachel while my mom took Emma outside. My phone's been blowing up all day with calls from Jake and Kelly's family calling me every name in the book. They're saying I made a pregnant woman cry and I'm heartless. Jake texted me that Kelly's so upset.
