I said, oh, that's weird because we don't even open for another 45 minutes. He just hung up without a word. 4, my ex wife told my kids I didn't pay child support regularly. I was able to lay out each and every receipt for three years showing each payment made on time or early. But I wouldn't say triumphant. There are no winners in divorce. 5, my friend's favorite is from when working at Mickey D's. She was on drive drive through and a guy came through complaining about the ice cream he got earlier. That's when everyone who worked there came to the drive through window to see. Friend casually lets them know they haven't had a working ice cream machine in four months. Six, at an auto shop, angry customer ahead of me was shouting, we've been here more than two hours. The shop manager gets out a piece of paper. We printed the work order you signed less than 30 minutes ago. Seven, I was waiting at a red light behind a red BMW. I saw that its bumper was kind of messed up. The light turns green and he starts going and I slowly accelerate. Like any normal human. Then he slams on his brakes and I do the same. Don't hit him at all. He reverses into my car and turns on his hazards and pulls into the shopping complex near us. We exchange information. I am absolutely calm. Later at small claims court after rejecting his claim with my insurance, he goes, yes, your honour, this rear ending left me with 5,000 in damage including paint and 1 thousand in emotional distress as I have needed physical therapy. Judge looks at me and you say you have video of this incident. Me. Yes, I do, sir. And I hand the CD to the bailiff. The dash cam clearly shows his fraud. Judge, so is that you in the video? Him. Um, he literally got arrested and had to pay me 5,000 in damages. Get a dash cam, people. 8. I had a customer once call and say she had bought these ice cream sandwiches the week before and they were all freezer burned. She was super aggressive and was yelling. So I very politely confirmed the exact product she bought. She yelled, yes, that one. That's what I've been telling you. And I said, miss, we discontinued those six months ago. She stuttered a bit and hung up. I was 19. It was my first job and it was so satisfying.

What's one thing your partner doesn't know? 1, she left her toxic ex boyfriend for me. He was always showing up in places she would be or randomly showing up at her house with no good intentions. She asked me not to get involved, so I respected her wishes for a while. he tried to break into her home one night while everyone was asleep. He got caught, made a run for it and keyed her car on the way out. Shortly after it happened, I was informed by a witness to the events. The witness expressed to me that at that time they were scared because they knew the ex boyfriend had been physically aggressive in the past and had recently tried to do it again as well. My girlfriend called me that night also but told me it was okay now and not to worry. For the next week, I staked out her house at night in case he tried again. I also found out where he lived and hung out and his routes to such places. I observed him and tracked his schedule. I waited for him to try something again and he came back to try and break in. Added security measures prevented him and after trying other ways, he left. He rode his bike down an isolated dirt path every morning as a shortcut to work. I waited and when I saw him, I blocked off his path with my vehicle. I did what? Had to be done and destroyed his bike. I told him if he even came near her again, even by accident, he wasn't going to walk away from it. An empty threat. I would have just roughed him up more at best. I also told him I recorded him trying to break into her house and damaging her property. I also read out to him in explicit detail his schedule and routines. I told him if I even thought he was sniffing around her again, I would find him. We never heard or saw from him again. We have been together for nearly 2 decades now. Very happy, successful and much so in love still. I swear I'm not a psycho, lol. I'm not possessive or an aggressive person. Everyone calls me a big teddy bear or a big softie. I grew up in a home with that kind of behavior and have zero tolerance for any of it. 2. Every time we go into a restaurant or place of business, I make sure to identify all the exit points in case something bad were to happen. Also never have my back to the doors. 3. I pretend to be asleep when he wakes up because I love how sweetly he wakes me up. 4. That I knew he was planning to propose to me, but I still acted surprised. We've been married 14 years now, but I still haven't told him. He is so proud of the idea that He managed to surprise me. 5. That I know their Reddit account. 6. That her mom called for her the moment before she passed when her mom was passing. She was in the room with her for almost 24 hours straight and left for 30 seconds and I was there in those 30 seconds. Her mother passed, but not before calling for my wife. I don't know if it will haunt her or not, but I just don't think it's something she needs to know. 7. He does not know that he was my teenage crush since I was 12 and I wrote so many beautiful poems about him. We have been married for six years and have a child together. I don't know if I will ever have the courage to tell him that I have always loved him. 8. That I have a folder of photos on my computer called Places I Have Found My Wife Shoes that is legitimately filled with thousands of pictures of my wife shoes that are neither in the closet or shoe rack. 9. That she's my partner. We rent together, go on dates, laugh together, cook together, eat together and talk about each other's day every evening. But she doesn't want a relationship right now. Before anyone says anything, I know how it sounds and I'm slowly making my way out of the situation. 10. Out of grocery shop efficiently. I can't stand going into the grocery store with her. She makes A list and then follows the list order through the store back and forth. She visits the same aisle three to four times.

What's the scariest thing you've woken up to? One, when he was little, my younger son wouldn't try and wake you up if he needed something. He'd do that creepy thing kids do where they just stand there looking at you until you wake up. Well, I wake up at about 1:00am in a dark bedroom and see the black silhouette of a young kid standing right next to the bed. Golly, that's scary. Then he asked, hey, dad, Wanna play Rock Band 2? Waking up to my husband yelling, get out of my house. A man broke into my house and crawled in bed with me. Turns out he was in the house for a couple of hours. According to my door camera, my husband was asleep on the couch, came to bed and found the guy on the bed beside me asleep. Also, I accidentally left my door unlocked when I lived in this studio apartment in Philly. I woke up and it felt like someone was watching me. You know that feeling. Then I heard a shuffling noise and turn the lights on. There was a guy in a hoodie standing at the foot of my bed. I screamed. It was a young drunk dude that I literally had to push out. He seemed confused, but I'll never know what his intent was. I've never left my door unlocked since 3. Once I woke up to go to the bathroom, got up, smack something, slap me in The face. Turns out it was my entire right arm. Completely numb. Nearly scared the piss out of me and concerned me greatly afterwards. Has not happened since. 4. Back when I lived alone in an apartment, I used to wake up to just about anything. Never woke up more terrified than the night when I woke up to the sound of my toilet flushing. To this day, I can only assume that a ghost just couldn't hold it anymore. Five, I woke up and my dad's alarm clock was going off through the wall. He was a really light sleeper and he always turned it off immediately. It had been going off for several minutes and I think I knew before I got to his room that he was no longer with me. It was just so incredibly out of character for that alarm to be going off like that. He went in his sleep with a blanket still completely undisturbed. And I think I felt some small comfort at that, even though I was just a kid. 6, I once woke up to an earthquake at 4:00am. I lived in a house over the ocean on stilts, so my house was rocking like crazy. It was my first earthquake. And for some reason my brain first thought that someone was robbing me. I grabbed a machete and ran outside shirtless in my underwear. Neighbors next to me looked at me alarmed and started laughing. 7, my partner waking. Me up during a camping trip. He woke me to gather all our gear and our dogs into our truck ASAP. Lightning we had spotted six hours earlier in the day had sparked a wildfire. We got out as ash and sparks were falling around us. When we reached the top of the ridge surrounding our camp, we got out to look and watch the fire eat our entire campsite. We're so glad we called in the strike when we saw it. We met fire crews on our way out. The fire burned for like a week. One of the fires in Oregon in 2020, the Lakeview Paisley Fire 8, a bed bug infestation. I had had them for weeks and had no idea what they were. I would see one or two here or there and I'd just squash them, wonder what they were and move on. One morning, I woke up early and found quite a few of them on my bed. I started looking more closely and realised that the creases of the mattress were infested with them. Then I started to do some research, Learned that I had bed bugs, felt my soul leave my body, then began the process of getting rid of them. They're a psychological horror experience I wouldn't wish upon my worst enemy. Five years after the fact, and I still get paranoia attacks at a random speck in the sheets or mysterious red marks in the morning.

What's the most ridiculous rule in your place of work? One. I once needed a pen. Figured this was a reasonable ask, went to the supply closet on my floor, which was locked. Asked the floors admin, and she told me to go to the main supply room in the basement. I went to the basement and explained my situation of needing a pen. They told me all requests for supplies must be approved by my department head. The problem is, being new, I'd never met my department head. She also worked in San Francisco. I worked in Milwaukee, so I needed to send an email both introducing myself and asking her if I had permission to get a pen from the supply closet. 2. All the extra toilet paper in the building has to stay in a single closet, where it can be overseen by the toilet paper queen. I heard her shrieking the other day when she discovered someone had hoarded one spare roll of toilet paper upstairs so the people who work upstairs wouldn't have to walk down multiple flights of stairs when the toilet paper ran out. It's the cheapest one ply toilet paper available on the giant rolls that only fit in the special dispensers. I can't imagine anyone wanting to steal it. Three. A rule that said if you have time to lean, you have time to clean. Which fairly obviously meant if there was no work, then you should be cleaning things. It Was at an aircraft servicing station that was fairly small, but we needed a crew of at least three people for larger planes. The problem was that sometimes there were just no planes, so there was no work. We would clean for a couple of hours and then just run out of stuff to clean. But according to management, that was no good. We had to be busy. It got to be that we would fight over work when it came in, because everyone was so bored. And finding pretend busy work was much harder than just working. I remember getting the crew together to pick up pebbles off the taxiway for a couple hours. There's an old joke in aviation. Go sweep the taxiway. So we actually did it. Four. I drive LA. The company handbook says you're never allowed to back up, ever. You absolutely cannot do the job without reversing. It's impossible. It's in there because of liability in our insurance policy. This way, it can always be the valet's fault if an accident occurs. Ever. The rule only exists to cover the company's rear. Five. When I was in the military, I saw a buddy of mine sitting outside crying. I went and consoled him as best as I could. Apparently, he was just unhappy. After he was feeling a bit better, I went to go and find someone to tell them what was happening. They knew. In fact, he had been crying so much lately, That they had instituted a no crying at your desk policy, which is why he was outside. 6. Empty inbox my boss was an inbox enforcer. Like if you had old emails in there he would flip and make you respond to them or delete them. Apparently you shouldn't have anything left at the end of the day. Deal with them or delete them. Jokes on him though, I just made a subfolder marked personal and everything went in there. 7. My workplace doesn't let you use the word problems. Instead we have to say challenges if something is wrong, as a problem is a negative word and challenges promotes the fact that there is room to fix said problem. 8. I used to work at a place in which my boss implemented a no more than two glasses a day water policy. I ignored this rule and complained directly to our CEO and the matter ended later that day. Nine. Can't have my hands in my pockets. 10. Business casual dress code. Even when I work at home they video call me to check. 11. No one can go to lunch between 12 and 2.

People who discovered a deal breaker partway through a date. What was the rest of the date like? One, first date from a dating app. We went for beverages at a hotel spot restaurant. When we were ordering the beverages, she said to the bartender, you can serve the restaurant menu here, right? I'll have the end. Proceeded to name the expensive dish she already knew by name. That was the there will be no second date red flag. The plan wasn't dinner, was a drink. Originally she had suggested an expensive restaurant, but I'd said let's just have a drink the first time, clearly just a foodie call. The I'm leaving now red flag was that she got on the phone and texted for a while, then said, my friends are coming to meet us. Let's order some more appetizers and a bottle. That was when I said the plan was some beverages to get to know each other, not be the wallet for your friends night out. I'll cover these beverages, have fun with your friends and left to pay my part of the Bill. Two, we matched on a dating app and he kept messaging me persistently, but he seemed like a nice guy. So he picked me up and took me to a decent sushi place. The actual dinner part went fine. Aside from him being very nervous and visibly sweating as he drove me home, he continually professed his love for me. By the time We got to my building. I was ready to book it as fast as possible into the entrance door which would lock behind me and he would be unable to enter without a key. Balked immediately. 3. An immediate red flag was that she told me she had no money and then she ordered the most expensive beverage on the list halfway through the date. She said she came from her ex boyfriend's house, but not to worry, they were no longer together. I finished my drink and excused myself to the bathroom. I tracked down our waitress and paid for our beverages. When I returned to the table, I told her I didn't think this was going to work out and left. Four, guy admitted to being technically homeless and crashing in a studio with two other guys. Told me he'd had 13 injuries that may have LED to memory loss. He didn't believe in key rings so he kept his keys on a rope, farted on a cat. I could go on. So much happened and all of it was unhinged. He got up to go to the bathroom and in a moment of inspiration and panic, I suddenly gained self awareness and realized I could leave. I threw money down on the bar top, made sympathetic eye contact with the bartender who had been watching the train wreck go down and then sprinted out of the restaurant. 5, she wanted to order lobster. I said, waiter, separate Bills, please. She glared at me, calling me broke while making the face. I ate my cheeseburger and fries and left her alone. Talk about spoiled. 6. We were having a very nice time, good chat, good company, etcetera. I looked over my shoulder to see the decor of the place we were in and she said, excuse me, I'm over here. She didn't like me not making eye contact all the time. If I looked away, she was insulted. The date ended and I drove away. 7, blind date, friend of a friend. He did not stop talking the entire time, didn't ask me one question. I just sat there mentally playing my favorite songs in my head until the Bill came. Because I'm a nice person and thought he might be nervous, I gave him another chance. The same thing happened over the phone. I fell asleep for 15 minutes and when I woke up, he was still talking. We did not meet up again. 8. She had never seen Star Wars. I'm not a fan. I don't even really like Star Wars. She brought up in conversation, complaining that her brother had become obsessed with the Star War. And that was it the whole rest of the date. Inside my head I asked myself, but how could she not know the name? Surely she's heard other people say it. Her brother has a lot of merch. She's read it many times. She doesn't have to care about It, but like, how is it even possible?

What is causing your friend to remain single that you don't have the heart to tell them one? The type of guy she claims she likes isn't what she's actually attracted to. She keeps saying how much she loves shy, introverted, sensitive guys, but when she finds one and dates him, suddenly he's not outgoing enough, doesn't speak his mind enough, and is too shy. I kind of think she has this I can fix him syndrome and doesn't really acknowledge it. Like she's attracted to the idea of a typical shy guy, but thinks once they're in a relationship they'll suddenly be more open and turn into the guy she actually wants. That's not how it works. 2. I can smell them. Everyone can smell them. I also had a coworker who started smelling like a poorly cleaned public restroom. Didn't smell like poop, but it was a terrible, almost chemical smell. I had a meeting with him. I had to make an excuse to leave the conference room because I felt like I was going to vomit. His manager finally took him aside and was like dude, what the crap is going on? Turns out he had started something that caused it and claimed he couldn't smell it. I have my doubts about this. He took a week off and came back smelling fine. Apparently his doctor swapped out his prescriptions and that was it. So maybe a similar situation. 3. I always wondered why she couldn't get A date because she is gorgeous. Until I saw her flirting with someone first night they met, flirted, swap numbers, then immediately clingy talking in a baby voice to him and making baby noises. He made a completely innocent comment which she found offensive and threatened him. Not shocking at all when he never called. Four really is not as nice of a person as he thinks he is. Five he keeps hanging on to the past and spending all his time hanging out with ex girlfriends who are unavailable or women who like him, but he doesn't romantically like. 6 the people they like aren't real. They are idealized, cartoonish caricatures. Now my friend himself has a lot to offer emo, but he is looking for a person that doesn't exist. Hard to find something that's not there. Seven she is so lovely, so kind, so generous, and so beautiful, but her crippling lack of self esteem is so huge it's visible from space. Basically, when she's nervous that she talks at 100 miles an hour in several directions at once. It's like being handed eight happy Labrador puppies to try and hold in your arms. I so badly want her to be happy and feel fulfilled, but even I find it tiring sometimes. 8 her standards are excessively too high. She brings nothing to a relationship. She's a walking contradiction. All of which is why she is single. I think it's great to have standards, but hers is Just a checklist of wants. 9 for my husband's friend, it's the selfish arrogance. I want what I want. And the subtext was that he never cared about what his girlfriend wanted. He would only go places he wanted to go, which never included her friends or family. He wanted to spend all his money on collectibles related to SCI fi movies, DVDs, figurines, etc. Engagement rings were a waste of money investing or buying a house. Ditto. No compromises were possible, he said no and no discussions were entertained. His opinion on every topic was the correct one and he was not interested in your opinion or listening to extra facts he did not know that might change his mind. 10 summarizing the two types of my single friends super successful, smart, funny, and good looking. They also tend to go for folks who leave them on read for days. Their self esteem is their own worst enemy. Other friends don't know how to commit to anything, including a job. It almost feels like an it'll happen when it happens type of ideology, and so they don't even try to make things happen.

What was something you saw you were definitely not supposed to see? One, when I was 14, a friend hosted a birthday party at his house with all the parents invited, needed to use the restroom, but the main one was occupied. So my friend told me I could use the one in his mom's bedroom. As I walked up to the door, I could hear somebody in there. So I decided to wait until whoever was in there was finished. A good 10 minutes later, my friend's mom, who was hosting the party and another good friend's stepfather walked out and saw me standing there all confused. They asked what I was doing there and I just said I was waiting to use the bathroom. Surprisingly, they played it cool and just said I can use it now and walked off. 2, I found my dad's will. I was on his computer while he was at work and ended up finding a strangely titled word document. First, it didn't seem like a big deal. It contained a note to each of his kids. It wasn't until I got to the last one, my youngest brother, then I realized it wasn't just a will. The start of that line read something along the lines of, if anything is going to make me change my mind, now it's writing. This part, I realized I had found my dad's note for his last moments. I was about 14 or 15 at the Time and I had no idea how to go about talking to him about it. I decided to just keep it to myself. He started buying us gifts and stuff and I would get really scared. 3. As a middle schooler, I picked up a book at the library, flipped through the pages and found an application for a replacement birth certificate for some old man. It had every detail about his personal identification on it. So naturally I took it home thinking I'll just hold on to this in case I ever need to assume a fake identity by pretending to be an 80 year old man and flee the country. My mom found it and had to explain to me that no, we don't steal people's identities. 4. I was about 8 or 9 and my parents were going to be out of town so they had me and my siblings stay with a family from our church. Once we got to the house, which was really nice by the way, they had one rule. You can play wherever you want but the basement is off limits. Being the little rascal that I was, snuck down there the first chance I got and was supremely disappointed to only find rows and rows of plants growing under lights. Looking back, I now know what it was. 5 when I started a new job, someone had left a bunch of HR files on the computer I was given. I opened One up, not sure what it was and I got to see every employee's salary in the company, even the CEO. The next day it was gone. My boss realized his mistake and logged into my system and deleted the files. It was a memorable experience. 6. I worked at a fancy health food restaurant years ago. One day I was early and saw the owner mixing his homemade cold pressed garlic aioli. It was Cisco mayonnaise and a big jar of minced garlic. 7. I was bartending and it was slow. I was putting away glasses by the only two people sitting at the bar. They seemed a new couple, very touchy, etcetera. At some point I noticed that she was wearing a wedding ring and he was not. Right. As the music silenced between songs, he turned to her and said, you know, they're going to ask you where you were when he passed. NOPED out of there real quick. Hey, my parents toy collection. That was way more reality than my 10 year old mind was prepared to handle. 9. My mother's autopsy report. My mom passed in a car accident because she pulled me out of the way of a speeding car. It, it was so unreal that I didn't even cry until years later. Several years later, I was probably 16 or 17 and looking into my dad's archive for some personal documentation about myself to submit a college application. Out of nowhere I opened This folder and found pictures of my mother lying on an operation table.

What's the pettiest reason you won't date someone? 1. I went on a breakfast date with a man one time. He spread ketchup across his entire plate and then chopped all the food into one big pile. Pancakes were involved. At that moment, I knew I could never see him again. Honestly, if they breathe or eat or swallow too loud, I can't handle it. It's petty, I know, but I can't do the rest of my life listening to someone breathe like a 70 year old man asleep on a chair or chew and swallow like a cow. 2, someone that takes forever to get ready to go literally anywhere. I once dated a girl and it literally took her 40 minutes to get ready to walk the dog for 15 minutes with me. Mind you, this was not a phobia. And for the record, she didn't wear any makeup nor did she wear anything special that might explain the sloth pace. Just basically talking my ears off and spending an eternity tying her shoelaces. It even left me with a small existential crisis, wondering if I would even be cut out for children. But choosing a life like this with an adult, I have way too little patience for that. Sorry. 3. This girl was beautiful, driven, intelligent. We got along well. She was perfect except that she would snap her fingers whenever someone would say something she liked. Every conversation peppered with snaps, she'd do it instead. Of applauding at concerts, too. Eventually I realized that this couldn't be my life. 4, the guy I married goes by his first and middle initials. Think J, C, L, J. And when I found out his actual first name about six months into dating him, it legitimately made me upset because it was such an old fashioned name. It didn't make me end, but I sure thought about it. To this day, 10+ years together, I avoid saying his proper name like the plague. I feel super petty about my feelings, but all these years later, I still really, really dislike it. I'm just used to it. Five, I once broke up with a girl because her teeth were small and the gaps between all her teeth really freaked me out. 6, I went on a first date with a guy at a coffee shop. I got there before him and was sitting at a table waiting. He walked up and instead of approaching and saying, excuse me, are you so and so, he very loudly yelled my name and everyone around turned and looked at him while I homered back into the bushes. It was over then and there. I think he thought he was being manly and dominant or something, but I'm a private and introverted person and that made my skin crawl. Seven, I swear to you, the day we got married, my wife started swallowing loudly like she knew it was a thing she did. She intentionally hit it and then stopped trying to hide it five seconds after our vows. 8, was married to someone. Then when that ended, I dated someone who had the same name. Years later, I was flirting with someone and when I Learned they had the same name, I just turned and walked away. 9. I won't date them if they don't use their turn signals. If you can't communicate on the road, you can't communicate in a relationship. 10. I dated a really cute lady in my early 20s. Pretty much my type, super sweet, but she did this weird exhale, scoff thing consistently in conversation when she didn't like something. And it became so noticeable I was going to lose my mind. I finally was just like, yeah, this isn't going to work. Eleven. They drag their feet when they're walking. 12. This was years ago, but I would swipe left on any dude holding an iPhone without a case on it cause I didn't need that kind of stress in my life. 13, allergies. I love animals and I'm not going to date a man who might pass away if I come around him after eating a peanut or shrimp.

People who bought a house, what is the weirdest thing you have found left by the previous owner? One first time I took a hot shower in our new home, the steam covered the mirror only to reveal the phrase, hello, I see you in large finger drawn writing. It freaked me out for a second but made me laugh soon after that. It was such an inconspicuous yet obvious thing to leave for the new homeowner. Me. Two, wasn't a purchase, but I was showing a house to a couple and we couldn't believe the reported square footage. It looked like a nice 1,700 square foot house in a semi rural community, but the square footage on the listing said about 4,500. I was sure it was a typo. Turns out most of it was in the basement. Think Buffalo Bills basement. That just goes on and on with random rooms. The place was vacant. The lighting wasn't great. We got to a dead end room down there and turned on the lights and there was this porcelain doll just chilling in the middle of the room. Only thing left in the house. Husband yells, screw this, and we all run out. We ruled out that whole neighborhood as an option for obvious reasons. 3, $1,200 in cash above the door on the inside of the closet. I found it while painting. 4, we bought a house being foreclosed on. We gave him an extra month after closing in. 2000 to help with his move. Still had to have the sheriff come to remove him. Anywho, I was doing some clean up and remodeling before we moved in. The whole house was carpeted. When I started ripping it out, there was a giant blood stain that started in a downstairs spare bedroom and then trailed up to the master bath where there was another stain. His wife had left him. So I had to call the realtor to find out if anyone knew where she was. Turns out he had taken out a deer in the yard and gutted it in the house. What a hassle. Had to rip up and install new sub floors. My vegan ex wife was not thrilled. 5. The property my wife and I moved to three years ago had a bucket full of wrapped Dinosaur bones. Took them to our local museum where they confirm they are roughly 68 million years old. Hadrosaur. Pretty cool. 6. We bought the house from the CEO of the company which we franchise from. It was her childhood home where her mother lived until the day she passed. In true rich person fashion, they didn't care to clean out the house before selling it. They just told us we can do whatever we want with the old lady stuff that was there. We found a hidden box of spicy letters from the old lady to her secret partner spanning many years. That was fun to give to the CEO 7, my uncle was renovating the house that he bought for his chiropractic practice. And when he knocked down a wall to enlarge a room, a few dozen pill bottles fell to the floor. They were each filled with about 25 US silver dollars, which at the time were worth more like $6 in silver each. So it was about $5,000 in vintage coins. 8, that they wired a room by connecting the outlet with an extension cord inside the wall. 9, a diary of an American soldier in World War 2 South Pacific Theater found it above a door when remodeling 20+ years ago. My wife and I tried everything we could think of to find a descendant, but to no avail. Ten, a basement room that was fully decked out as a dungeon. Fake stone walls, a stocks like where you lock your head and hands in Old England. Candle scones on the walls, a metal barred cage in the corner from floor to ceiling. Oh, and the closet had a load of toys, some normal, some not so normal. 11, an entire tribe of raccoons living in the attic.

What loophole did you exploit before someone found out? 1. My old apartment complex had a soda vending machine at the pool that was broken. If you put in 50 cents and press the button, nothing happened. If you put in another 50 cents and press the button, nothing happened. But if you put 50 cents in a third time and press the button, you'd get three sodas. I could see the vending machine from my couch, so I would watch for someone to try and then try again and then give up without trying a third time. And then I'd head over and get three sodas for 50 cents. Two. Not me, but my roommate. In college, whenever you paid for anything on the university's website, you'd earn college bucks, each year's tuition, pay for something small like a beer, koozie, fold up lawn chair, or if you somehow spent an absurd amount, an official school branded kayak. Well, my buddy found out that the points were added to your account before payment went through on the website. So he just refreshed the page over and over and got millions of points. I only found out about his scheme when I came home to an entire living room filled with boxes from our school. There were shirts, coolers, chairs, cups and, of course, the kayak. We opened all of it like idiots and had a giant laugh at the school's expense. All of the guys living in that house. Were having a great time until we opened the smallest box which had 1,100 dollar visa gift cards. Then we got scared. A bunch of school branded crap from a warehouse was probably unusual, but not something that would bother the person loading all that up for delivery. The gift cards though, that was where he got caught. The gift card issuer called the school to verify such a large amount before activating the cards and that raised a lot of red flags in the accounting department. They traced it all back to my roommate and came and took everything back. They left the opened items in the worthless gift cards and suspended him during his final semester of college. He had to write an apology letter and do community service for the school for that whole semester in return for not pressing charges for fraud. It makes for a great story though. We had a ton of beer, koozies and gift cards that we threw at each other like Ninja Stars 3. When in high school, there was a company that offered money to run an advertising window at the top of your screen would monitor mouse movement to track whether you were at your computer and pay a small amount per hour. A buddy and I downloaded it and a mouse moving software and it would run both 24 7 except when we were on the computer. Made a few hundred dollars off of it before the company Closed down 4 Coca Cola did a campaign where you register a code from the bottle cap and earn prizes I worked at a store with a bottle deposit and earn myself a sweet MP three player with room for five songs or something. It was pretty sweet at the time. 5 had a college professor who insisted on doing all tests and quizzes online. If you looked at the page through view page source all of the answers for each multiple answer question had a marker on which one was correct. 6 free sandwiches from CFA based on location I used GPS spoofer and got tons of free sandwiches a week on multiple accounts. I think I got about $5,000 worth of sandwiches and nuggets before they banned me. 7 I received thousands of dollars of stock certificates in the mail. Some intern messed up so badly that my broker said to hold on to it I I held the stock for years before selling it at a profit. 8 I Learned before my USAF basic training to say that I played an instrument whenever they asked the group on the first day I raised my hand and lied and said the symbols so most days I got to angrily smash symbols together in the air conditioning band trailer.

Which memorable Reddit post slash comment can you still not get over? One. The grandma who used coconut oil on her granddaughter who was extremely allergic and passed from it. As someone who works with toddlers, that story is a nightmare. Grandma nonchalantly caused the passing of her granddaughter. Not because she didn't know about the allergy, because she just didn't think it was a big deal. And in no time flat, a toddler is gone and two parents and two surviving siblings are forever traumatized. And grandma can't figure out why her daughter won't see her two. It wasn't as memorable or as big as most Reddit comments, but one has stuck with me. I forgot what the question was, but this guy commented that he was asked to bring like two gallons of milk to his girlfriend's family dinner. He thought, oh, they must really like milk. When he arrived, each family member had their own gallon of milk, and when dinner was served they all just started guzzling their own milk like animals. I need to try finding that. It was hilarious. 3 the one where the guy had an imaginary girlfriend, later wife, who was a giant cockroach, and his coworkers eventually found out that he had a whole fantasy life with his life size cockroach girlfriend slash wife. Four people seem to regularly post what Reddit post can't you get over? And I always drop in to say the pregnant woman whose husband and father In law decided she'd pass in labor and we're doing all the planning for that to happen. She never updated and I always wonder and worry a little. Wish I'd save the post. 5 the guy who was looking for legal advice because his landlord was sneaking in and leaving him notes while he was sleeping and someone in the comment section saved his life by realizing he was actually suffering carbon monoxide poisoning. Six the lady on ADA who unplugged her fridge to deep clean it while her husband had a box in there who told her to not open the box. I frequently wonder what was in the box. 7 the dude that bought a house with his GF and wasn't allowed upstairs. I want an update to this more than any unsolved mystery. 8 the guy who caught his wife cheating thanks to his Dyson fan epic. 9 the guy who Rick rolled Rick Astley.

I watched so much TikTok, it ended up saving a life. My first few months as a 9 1 1 operator were scary, but nothing could have prepared me for when I got a call late at night from a young girl. I could barely understand what she was saying through her sobbing, but she told me she had just swallowed an entire bottle of pills and just wanted someone to talk to before they did anything. I started asking her why she would do that and asked for her address. She thought I already had it. But after a few minutes, she finally told me where she lived. She said she was severely depressed and just wanted everything to end. I asked her why, just trying to keep her on the phone and she said she couldn't take the hate she was getting anymore. I knew I only had literal minutes to do something and tried talking her into throwing up. She told me no. So I asked her what kind of hate she was getting. Apparently, she just wanted people to like her and wanted to help people. She was getting a lot of hate comments on TikTok and even people in real life. Then it all clicked. I knew I recognized her voice and I actually knew who she was. After a few minutes, I asked her if she was who I thought and she was really surprised. I started to tell her how one of her Videos actually changed my life and got me out of a toxic relationship. She knew I wasn't lying because I told her all about it. I asked her one more time and she finally agreed to try and make herself throw up. She was unconscious when the paramedics got there, but because of that, she was still alive. She now has millions of followers and I'm glad to see her much happier today.

My son made a kid cry on his birthday and I was so proud of him. When my son was in the third grade, he was a bully. We tried everything, but he kept constantly getting in trouble and sent to the office. He was known throughout the school for tying balloons to the class rabbit and almost letting it float away. I was leaving work to go get him and as my phone rang, I already knew who it was. I had a special ringtone for his teacher because she called me so much just so I could prepare to hear what he did. She was crying when I answered and I knew it was bad. I told her I was on the way, but instead of getting upset, she started to thank me. I was really confused and she started to talk about what a sweet boy I raised. Literally nobody had ever told me that before for. And I asked what happened. Apparently another kid who didn't have a lot of friends was in his class and his mom had handed out birthday invitations to everyone the day before. Right before the bell went off, he stood up in front of everyone and asked who was coming to his party. The entire class was now silent and he just stood there looking around for someone to tell him they were going. Nobody was saying anything. And she said she could see the kids heart literally breaking in Real time. Then, as he went to sit back down in shame, my son stood up and said, I'm gonna come. I'll be there. His face lit up, and one by one, all the other boys in the class followed his lead and also started telling him they'd come, too. He was trying not to cry when we showed up that weekend.

People who got expelled from school. What did you do in 9th grade? I got the teacher everybody wanted for biology. Except one morning our entire class could hear her outside the room getting chewed out by our assistant principal for being late on grading. We also knew she had lost her sister the week before, so she was having a really rough time. A few minutes into teaching, she started explaining something about our final exam and the guys next to me were passing notes. They usually did it every time she turned around, but this time she saw them. She usually wouldn't have cared, but she thought it was something about her. So she walked over and asked to see it. Kid shook his head without saying anything. So she basically reached into his pocket to grab the note. She started reading it in front of the class and said, I left it in the garbage bin in room W12. It's all there with the. And stopped herself before reading the rest out loud. She looked down at the boy, clearly having read something bad and didn't know what to say. Her face was pale and not knowing what to do. She grabbed them both and literally yanked them out of the room. We all sat there confused for a half hour wondering what that note said. There were police at our school and they asked our whole route to come to the office. They questioned everybody about It, but nobody knew anything. And by the time they let us go, they had sent everybody home. We later found out that the note said there was a key to the office in that garbage bin along with a loaded gun. Both of them denied writing it and said they didn't know who it was for. So they decided to fire our teacher for creating a school wide panic and expelled our entire row.

What was the most illegal thing that happened at your school? A few students decided to play a senior prank on the principal by writing on his car. And it made him so mad he decided to cancel the entire prom for the year. Everyone was pissed. So at the homecoming game the week after, we were chanting to bring it back. Eventually at the end, some kid with a banana suit jumped over the bleachers and ran across the field. Everyone screamed as he was being chased by coaches and teachers, and even the players loved it. Eventually, they tackled him hard and he ended up breaking his arm and had to go to the hospital. They had to cancel the game and the staff were so mad they suspended him for the rest of the year. He was probably gonna get expelled, but the students loved him so much, they decided they were gonna do something about it. That day, free Banana Man was born and everyone started chanting it in the halls. Few guys sold t shirts that said it and they wrote it all over the walls. At our school, there were bananas everywhere. And this made our principal so mad, he banned the phrase entirely. However, he didn't just stop there. He decided to go as far as to ban the actual fruit itself and even the entire color yellow. You literally weren't allowed to wear yellow to school. And if you were caught eating A banana, you were sent home for the day. This rule made the entire student body so furious they pretty much declared a war on the administration. Hundreds of students were getting sent home because they decided to bring bananas and wear yellow. And when they tell them to take their yellow shirts off, they'd walk around shirtless to class. I even saw a guy come to school in all yellow, and when they made him take it off, he tried to go to class only in his underwear, which was also yellow. It got so crazy that one kid who literally needed to eat bananas for the potassium couldn't for the week and ended up passing out in the middle of class. He went to the hospital and his parents threatened to sue the school. The very next day, we watched our principal walk out for the last time and the banana guy returned wearing his costume.

My teacher thought I was cheating on a test, so she sent me to the er. When I was in 9th grade, I got stuck with our school's worst teacher, who was infamous for trying to make a Muslim girl take off her headwear to prove she wasn't wearing headphones in class. There were a lot of students who got away with cheating by wearing headphones during tests, so she was constantly checking. Since then, she didn't do anything too bad until we had to take our final exam at the end of the year and she stood up to walk around the room. It was really hot that day, so I wore a lighter shirt. I also happened to have type 1 diabetes, so you could see my insulin pump. That day, my blood sugar was low, so I turned my pump on and walked into class. We were almost done taking the test and she stood up to walk around the room. I was honestly focused on just passing until I heard her walk straight up behind me. In that moment, two things happened. She grabbed my paper off my desk and told me I failed. And I felt her grab the pump on my waist. I just sat there in shock as she walked away and had no idea what had just happened. However, it wasn't until I noticed she was holding Scissors that it clicked what she had just done. She seen the wire hanging off My waist and assumed I had headphones in. When I looked down, the tube was cut. After a few seconds, my pump started beeping very loudly and everyone started looking at me. A few people sitting around me saw what happened and were in shock. She came over and when she realized what she did, I watched her face turn pale. She had messed up big time and had no idea what to do and neither did I. She told me to go to the nurse and on the way there, I started getting, see, I made it there, could feel myself starting to pass out. The nurse called 9 1 1 and I had to go to the hospital. But since that day, I actually started wearing headphones in class because none of the teachers would try anything.

Teachers, what's the saddest thing you found out about a student? I taught 5th grade for a few years and had to stay up really late one night to grade some essays. I was exhausted, but I remember reading one of them and couldn't believe what I saw. I told my class to write about a funny story, and this girl, Kelly, wrote about how her mom had almost killed her. She said her mom woke her and her brothers up one morning yelling at them because someone ate a candy from her room. All of them denied it, so they had to stand in a corner until one of them admitted they had eaten it. After an hour, nobody said anything. So their mom stepped it up. She was determined to find who did it, so she made all of them drink an entire cup of salt water until they vomited. She said her throat hurt so much she started crying. I couldn't believe I was reading this and thought she had to have been making it up. I knew her mom and she seemed so nice. She said whoever ate it would have to sleep outside that night. And when she was about to get another glass of salt water, her brother stepped up. He said he took it and her mom was furious. She was literally moving his bed outside. But as she did, their dad came home and had no idea what was going on when He found out it was because of the candy. He told them he was the one who ate it. This was supposed to be her funny story. This girl was 9 and there was no way she was making this up. I couldn't just go to bed. So I called and woke our student advisor up and read her essay word for word over the phone. She, too, didn't believe it was real. So we asked her about it the next day at school. Apparently she just thought it was a funny story and didn't think her mom was being too mean. We had to report. But as soon as someone went out to talk to her parents, she took her daughter out of the school. I hope she's doing okay. Update. I just saw her on the news. She was arrested and put in jail last night.

My mom almost ended my life, but her gut feeling saved me. I remember sitting in math when the bell rang and I started walking towards the library to eat lunch. I was starving. There was nowhere to sit except the very back. As soon as I sat down, I remember hearing a sound from the hallway that sounded like a door slamming onto the ground. Nobody really reacted. But then we heard a girl screaming outside the library. She came running down the hallway and we heard the noise again. It was so silent in there until she yelled, somebody help, he has a gun. And everyone completely panicked. I remember freezing up because I didn't know where to go. The room was all windows and everyone started flooding out the back door. I move and another guy went to hide in a utility closet behind us. He told me to come inside, so I did. We sat there silently crying for about five minutes, slugging our ears. It felt like hours. And everyone screaming was gone. It was so quiet. So we opened the window on the door slightly to see out. As soon as I did, I saw they were inside the library. We stayed as silent as we possibly could and my mom wouldn't stop texting me. We couldn't move, but I realized if my mom calls me, my phone would go off. If she called me, we probably wouldn't survive. We sat there with our Hands over our mouths, trying to breathe as quietly as we could. And I was praying they wouldn't look inside. We could hear them right outside the closet we were in. But they started running out and we heard the police in the school. We sat there for another hour until the police found us and we made it out safe. When I asked my mom why she didn't call me, she said she didn't want it to ring in case I might be hiding.

She told me to go to the nurse, and on the way there, I started getting. I made it there. Could feel myself starting to pass out. The nurse called 9 1 1 and I had to go to the hospital. But since that day, I actually started wearing headphones in class because none of the teachers would try anything.

Parents, what do your kids think they're hiding from you? My 13 year old son, Alex asked if he could download a chess app on his tablet. I was shocked. All his friends were begging for Fortnite or some zombie game, and here's my kid wanting to play chess. I said yes immediately. See, I'm pretty strict about screen time. No games, no social media. Homework first. Alex has always been quiet, kind of awkward around other kids. Chess seemed perfect for building his brain. He got obsessed fast. Every day after school, straight to his room with that tablet. I'd hear him muttering moves under his breath. Night to E4, check. When I asked how it was going, he'd light up, talking about strategy and logic patterns. Months in, I noticed something weird. He'd quickly close the tablet whenever I walked in. Said he was just thinking through positions. Then one night, I heard him talking. Not muttering chess moves, actually talking to someone. I knocked. Who are you talking to? Just practicing out loud, dad. Helps me think. My gut said something was wrong. Next day, I checked his tablet while he was at school. The chess app was deleted. Completely gone. When I asked him about it, he said he took a break and was doing puzzles in his head now. That's when I installed tracking software. Took me three days to figure out how, but I did it. What I found made my blood boil. He'd Been using a fake chess app that was actually a cover for some underground gambling site. He was playing speed chess for money against adults online. Real money. His username was Chess Master J, and he had over $400 in his account. I watched one of his matches through the tracker. My quiet, awkward kid was trash talking grown men like some kind of gaming streamer. You call that a defense? My little sister plays better than you. Then he destroyed them in under five minutes with moves I couldn't even follow. But here's the crazy part. I kept watching, and this wasn't some gambling addiction. The kid was genuinely incredible. He was beating adults who'd been playing for decades. One guy even accused him of cheating and demanded a video call. Alex turned on his camera, solved three chess puzzles in 30 seconds, then checkmated the guy in seven moves while explaining every decision. I dug deeper into his account. Turns out he'd been banned from our school's chess team six months ago for embarrassing another school's coach during a live tournament. Coach had called Alex a know it nothing kid. So Alex responded by beating him in front of 200 people while explaining each mistake the coach made. The school said it was unsportsmanlike conduct. Alex never told me. Just said he quit the team because it was boring. So for months, he'd been rebuilding his reputation online, earning money, and getting revenge on everyone who'd written him Off the fake chess app. Wasn't about being lazy. It was about hiding how good he actually was. That night at dinner, I put a chess board between us. Wanna play a quick game? His face went white. Dad, I don't really. One game. Humor your old man.

What was the most illegal thing that happened at your school? A few students decided to play a senior prank on the principal by writing on his car. And it made him so mad he decided to cancel the entire prom for the year. Everyone was pissed. So at the homecoming game the week after, we were chanting to bring it back. Eventually at the end, some kid with a banana suit jumped over the bleachers and ran across the field. Everyone screamed as he was being chased by coaches and teachers, and even the players loved it. Eventually, they tackled him hard and he ended up breaking his arm and had to go to the hospital. They had to cancel the game and the staff were so mad they suspended him for the rest of the year. He was probably gonna get expelled, but the students loved him so much, they decided they were gonna do something about it. That day, free Banana Man was born and everyone started chanting it in the halls. Few guys sold t shirts that said it and they wrote it all over the walls. At our school, there were bananas everywhere. And this made our principal so mad, he banned the phrase entirely. However, he didn't just stop there. He decided to go as far as to ban the actual fruit itself and even the entire color yellow. You literally weren't allowed to wear yellow to school. And if you were caught eating A banana, you were sent home for the day. This rule made the entire student body so furious they pretty much declared a war on the administration. Hundreds of students were getting sent home because they decided to bring bananas and wear yellow. And when they tell them to take their yellow shirts off, they'd walk around shirtless to class. I even saw a guy come to school in all yellow, and when they made him take it off, he tried to go to class only in his underwear, which was also yellow. It got so crazy that one kid who literally needed to eat bananas for the potassium couldn't for the week and ended up passing out in the middle of class. He went to the hospital and his parents threatened to sue the school. The very next day, we watched our principal walk out for the last time and the banana guy returned wearing his costume.

Teachers, what's the saddest thing you found out about a student? I taught fifth grade for a few years and had to stay up really late one night to grade some essays. I was exhausted, but I remember reading one of them and couldn't believe what I saw. I told my class to write about a funny story, and this girl, Kelly, wrote about how her mom had almost killed her. She said her mom woke her and her brothers up one morning yelling at them because someone ate a candy from her room. All of them denied it, so they had to stand in a corner until one of them admitted they had eaten it. After an hour, nobody said anything, so their mom stepped it up. She was determined to find who did it, so she made all of them drink an entire cup of salt water until they vomited. She said her throat hurt so much, she started crying. I couldn't believe I was reading this and thought she had to have been making it up. I knew her mom, and she seemed so nice. She said whoever ate it would have to sleep outside that night. And when she was about to get another glass of salt water, her brother stepped up. He said he took it, and her mom was furious. She was literally moving his bed outside. But as she did, their dad came home and had no idea what was going on. When He found out it was because of the candy. He told them he was the one who ate it. This was supposed to be her funny story. This girl was 9, and there was no way she was making this up. I couldn't just go to bed, so I called and woke our student advisor up and read her essay word for word over the phone. She, too, didn't believe it was real, so we asked her about it the next day at school. Apparently, she just thought it was a funny story and didn't think her mom was being too mean. We had to report, but as soon as someone went out to talk to her parents, she took her daughter out of the school. I hope she's doing okay. Update? I just saw her on the news. She was arrested and put in jail last night.

People who got expelled from school, what did you do in ninth grade? I got the teacher everybody wanted for biology. Except one morning, our entire class could hear her outside the room getting chewed out by our assistant principal for being late on grading. We also knew she had lost her sister the week before, so she was having a really rough time. A few minutes into teaching, she started explaining something about our final exam, and the guys next to me were passing notes. They usually did it every time she turned around, but this time she saw them. She usually wouldn't have cared, but she thought it was something about her, so she walked over and asked to see it. Kid shook his head without saying anything, so she basically reached into his pocket to grab the note. She started reading it in front of the class and said, I left it in the garbage bin in room W12. It's all there with the. And stopped herself before reading the rest out loud. She looked down at the boy, clearly having read something bad and didn't know what to say. Her face was pale, and not knowing what to do, she grabbed them both and literally yanked them out of the room. We all sat there confused for a half hour, wondering what that note said. There were police at our school, and they asked our whole row to come to the office. They questioned everybody about It. But nobody knew anything and by the time they let us go they had sent everybody home. We later found out that the note said there was a key to the office in that garbage bin along with a loaded gun. Both of them denied writing it and said they didn't know who it was for. So they decided to fire our teacher for creating a school wide panic and expelled our entire row.

How did you become a millionaire? When I was 17, my mom forced me to start babysitting, but I had no idea who I was doing it for. When I met this woman, I couldn't believe how overprotective she was. She had cameras in every room of the house and asked me to call her every half hour just to make sure her daughter was okay. She told me I wasn't allowed to do anything except watch her. And when she finally left, I basically just sat there for three hours doing nothing until she came home. She came back and basically ran into the room to make sure the girl was okay and I assured her everything was fine. I had long hair at the time and had put it up at this point. And should probably now mention I have severe hearing loss. I have to wear hearing aids, which can usually be easily mistaken for headphones. Then as I was standing up to say bye to the girl, her mom noticed them in my ears. She thought I was wearing headphones the whole time and wasn't paying attention to the little girl. This made her furious and a second later, I felt her grab my head. All I remember was feeling the worst pain I've ever felt in my ear. I turned around to see her holding my hearing aid and realized what she did. She thought I was listening to music. She ripped my hearing aid. Out of my ear, thinking it was a headphone. And since they connect directly to my eardrum, she completely ripped that out, too. The pain was so intense I passed out and woke up in the hospital to my mom crying. She was livid. And even though they begged us not to, we sued her. I will never hear out of my ear again, but I'll never have to work again either.

I watched so much TikTok, it ended up saving a life. My first few months as a 9 1 1 operator were scary, but nothing could have prepared me for when I got a call late at night from a young girl. I could barely understand what she was saying through her sobbing, but she told me she had just swallowed an entire bottle of pills and just wanted someone to talk to before they did anything. I started asking her why she would do that and asked for her address. She thought I already had it, but after a few minutes she finally told me where she lived. She said she was severely depressed and just wanted everything to end. I asked her why. Just trying to keep her on the phone and she said she couldn't take the hate she was getting anymore. I knew I only had literal minutes to do something and tried talking her into throwing up. She told me no, so I asked her what kind of hate she was getting. Apparently she just wanted people to like her and wanted to help people. She was getting a lot of hate comments on TikTok and even people in real life. Then it all clicked. I knew I recognized her voice and I actually knew who she was. After a few minutes I asked her if she was who I thought and she was really surprised. I started to tell her how one of her Videos actually changed my life and got me out of a toxic relationship. She knew I wasn't lying because I told her all about it. I asked her one more time, and she finally agreed to try and make herself throw up. She was unconscious when the paramedics got there, but because of that, she was still alive. She now has millions of followers, and I'm glad to see her much happier today.

Have you ever seen a teacher get fired? I went to a public school that love to control its students and one day they introduced the dumbest rule I've ever heard. Apparently they thought too many people were out in the halls instead of learning. So one morning they announced that students were no longer allowed to go to the bathroom during class. I literally thought it was a joke at first people started getting detention for being in the halls during class. Didn't matter how bad you had to pee, you simply weren't allowed to go. I remember watching a few people sit through class in pain because they couldn't go. But that was nothing compared to one girl. We were in art class and that teacher had got into multiple arguments with our principal about the rule. A lot of people loved this teacher, but I think our principal even threatened to fire him. So when a girl in my class was dying to go pee, he couldn't let her. She ended up sitting there in pain butting for 20 minutes and wasn't gonna make it until lunch. So since he wasn't gonna let her pee her pants in front of all her friends, our art teacher decided to walk her over to our art storage room. He stood outside the door and she peed in a bucket. Pretty good move on his part. Now, he wasn't gonna lose his job. That's what you think. Turns out A few bratty kids in our class knew what she did and started telling their parents. The news of it spread, and soon enough, reporters were at our school questioning him. The next day, there was a news article about how that teacher made the girl pee in a bucket but didn't mention our school's rule at all. Our school's administration panicked, and guess who they blamed? They fired him for creating an unsafe environment.
NA

My son made a kid cry on his birthday and I was so proud of him. When my son was in the third grade, he was a bully. We tried everything, but he kept constantly getting in trouble and sent to the office. He was known throughout the school for tying balloons to the class rabbit and almost letting it float away. I was leaving work to go get him and as my phone rang, I already knew who it was. I had a special ringtone for his teacher because she called me so much just so I could prepare to hear what he did. She was crying when I answered and I knew it was bad. I told her I was on the way, but instead of getting upset, she started to thank me. I was really confused and she started to talk about what a sweet boy I raised. Literally nobody had ever told me that before. And I asked what happened. Apparently another kid who didn't have a lot of friends was in his class and his mom had handed out birthday invitations to everyone the day before. Right before the bell went off, he stood up in front of everyone and asked who was coming to his party. Entire class was now silent and he just stood there looking around for someone to tell him they were going. Nobody was saying anything and she said she could see the kids heart literally breaking in real time. Then as he went to sit back down in shame, my son stood up and said, I'm gonna come. I'll be there. His face lit up, and one by one all the other boys in the class followed his lead and also started telling him they'd come, too. He was trying not to cry when we showed up that weekend.

My mom almost ended my life, but her gut feeling saved me. I remember sitting in math when the bell rang, and I started walking towards the library to eat lunch. I was starving. There was nowhere to sit except the very back. As soon as I sat down, I remember hearing a sound from the hallway that sounded like a door slamming onto the ground. Nobody really reacted, but then we heard a girl screaming outside the library. She came running down the hallway, and we heard the noise again. It was so silent in there until she yelled, somebody help! He has a gun! And everyone completely panicked. I remember freezing up because I didn't know where to go. The room was all windows, and everyone started flooding out the back door. I move, and another guy went to hide in a utility closet behind us. He told me to come inside, so I did. We sat there silently crying for about five minutes, slugging our ears. It felt like hours. And everyone screaming was gone. It was so quiet. So we opened the window on the door slightly to see out. As soon as I did, I saw they were inside the library. We stayed as silent as we possibly could, and my mom wouldn't stop texting me. We couldn't move, but I realized if my mom calls me, my phone would go off. If she called me, we probably wouldn't survive. We sat there with our Hands over our mouths, trying to breathe as quietly as we could. And I was praying they wouldn't look inside. We could hear them right outside the closet we were in. But they started running out, and we heard the police in the school. We sat there for another hour until the police found us. And we made it out safe. When I asked my mom why she didn't call me, she said she didn't want it to ring in case I might be hiding

Has your school ever had a real lockdown? A really well known celebrity that graduated from our high school was coming to speak one morning and a lot of the girls were really excited. But an hour before it was supposed to start, we were told to go to the gym and not bring anything. When I walked in, there were police dogs and officers searching everybody. Nobody really thought it was weird because this person was famous. But when everyone was inside the gym, we were told we weren't allowed to leave. This is when it started to seem weird. And after a while, some people were asking to go to the bathroom. They had to be escorted by police officers and they started asking every guy wearing a gray shirt to come down and talk to them. Lunch passed and people were getting angry and we had to eat in the gym. Nobody knew what was happening and none of the teachers would say anything. cops kept showing up to talk to people and wouldn't let anyone leave. One guy tried to fight one of the cops when he wouldn't let him out and they actually arrested him. It was past the end of school and still nobody was allowed out of the gym. Parents couldn't pick us up either because they couldn't even come on the property. the entire school was surrounded and everyone was getting really mad. So our principal finally told us what Was going on. She sounded really on edge and told us the police were searching the school because there was a bomb threat in one of the bathrooms. I'll never forget how quiet it was and everyone was terrified. Nobody was allowed to leave until they found who did it. But after a half hour, they took another kid down and arrested him. We all knew it was him because we were allowed to leave after. But it was surprising because he was one of the popular guys. Everyone knew this was super weird for him. But the next morning we found out what happened and nobody could believe they looked through the cameras for the entire day because one of our older teachers had heard a boy in a gray shirt say something in the hallway. Turns out he completely misunderstood what he meant when he overheard him telling another boy that he was going to blow up the bathroom later that day.

NA

I pretended not to recognize my parents when they tried to reconnect. So this whole thing starts when I'm 6 years old. My older sister gets really sick with some autoimmune thing that basically makes her need constant care. Instead of figuring it out like normal parents would, mine just decided I was too much work on top of everything else. One day they're like, hey, you're gonna visit grandma for a bit. And literally just never came back for me. No explanation, no this is temporary, nothing. Just dropped me off like I was a library book they forgot to return. My Uncle Jake and Aunt Linda ended up taking me in because my grandparents were getting too old to handle a kid full time. At first I kept asking when mom and dad were coming back, but after a few months everyone had to sit me down and explain that they probably weren't. My uncle was so pissed he couldn't even talk about it without getting red in the face. My aunt just hugged me and said, sometimes parents make really stupid decisions and it's not the kids fault. The weird thing is, it actually worked out better. My uncle and aunt couldn't have kids of their own, so they treated me like I was this amazing gift that just showed up. They came to every school play, helped with homework, taught me to drive, all that stuff. They always joke that the stork just got confused and Delivered me to the wrong house first. When I turned 18, they officially adopted me. We would have done it earlier, but apparently there was all this legal stuff that would have cost, like $15,000. I saw my bio parents maybe five times over the next 15 years. Always awkward encounters at family stuff where they try to act like everything was normal. By the time I was 12, I realized I was the only one making any effort to maintain contact. So I just stopped. They never reached out after that. Not for birthdays, not for graduation, nothing. Then last December, my sister died. Some complication with her condition right between Thanksgiving and Christmas. I drove back from college for the funeral, but stayed in the very back row and slipped out before anyone could corner me. My uncle said they called asking to talk to me, but I told him I wasn't interested. Christmas Eve, I'm at midnight mass with my grandma, like we do every year. We're walking out after the service when suddenly these two people appear in front of me. The woman goes in for a hug, and I instinctively step back. Sorry, do I know you? I asked, even though I totally recognized them. The man looked older, more tired. The woman had the same nervous laugh she always had. Where are your parents? The woman said, like that explained everything. I looked at them for a second, then shrugged. My parents are at Home watching die hard and probably falling asleep on the couch. They both just stood there with their mouths open. My grandma grabbed my arm and we kept walking, but I could feel them following us. The man caught up and walked beside me. You really don't recognize us? He asked. I stopped and looked at him like I was trying to remember. Oh, wait. Are you my dad's brother? I think I remember you from

Like that explained everything. I looked at them for a second, then shrugged. My parents are at Home watching Die Hard and probably falling asleep on the couch.
