Secret signs A boy likes you but is just shy. The last one will shock you. His body language gives him away. He sneaks, glances at you, but quickly looks away when you notice. His feet or body are often pointed toward you. He plays with his hands, adjust clothes, taps foot when you're around. TikTok knows someone who has feelings for you, but it's too afraid to tell you it's the second person. When you click share and more, he gets nervous around you. His voice cracks or he stumbles over words. When talking to you, he finds small excuses to be near you. He shows up where you are more often than coincidence allows. He remembers the little things. Comment I hate when and let your keyboard finish the sentence. Even if he doesn't talk much, he notices details about you, like your favourite snack, something you said weeks ago. He pays attention in ways others might overlook. He interacts differently with you than with others. He may be loud and confident with friends, but quiet around you. He engages online more than in person. He texts, comments, or likes your posts, but is quieter face to face. He's more relaxed when there's no direct eye contact. Before the last fact. Please like the video and follow or you might never see me again. His friends know something. They tease him when you're around. They may drop hints or act differently toward you because they know how he Feels

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball when our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids'grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I've forgotten how to enjoy my Children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and be being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after three years of Zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck, pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she owned the plate.

My wife demanded we swap partners with her best friend, so I went along with it. My wife Stephanie, waited until we were eating dessert at Cassie and Paul's house to drop this on me. We should swap partners every Thursday, she said, and I literally watched her put her hand on Paul's thigh under the table. I saw it. Cassie saw it, too, and her face went blank. What? I asked because I honestly thought I heard her wrong. Partner swapping. We date each other's spouses. Said it like she was talking about switching cars for the weekend. Paul kept staring at his plate and wouldn't make eye contact with me. It's already decided, Stephanie said. Thursday nights, you take Cassie out, Paul takes me. I felt my chest get tight. When did they decide this without me? This is insane, I told her. Then she leaned in close and whispered, room 2:37 last Tuesday when you were at work. My whole body went numb. She was telling me she'd already cheated and now wanted my permission to keep doing it. So are you in or not? She asked louder. I looked at Cassie, and she was crying without making any sound. Fine, I said. Let's swap partners. Stephanie smiled like she just won something, but. And I noticed Cassie had stopped crying completely. That should have told me something right there. When the first date night came around, Stephanie spent forever getting ready. She put on this red Dress I'd never seen before that she'd been hiding in our closet. Paul's car was already running in our driveway when I left. I brought Cassie white roses because I remembered she mentioned liking them once. Her hands shook when she took them. Paul? Never. She started, then stopped. At dinner. She pushed her food around and barely ate anything. You okay? I asked. Paul's been different, she said quietly. For months, even before. Then she stopped talking again. I reached over and touched her hand. Before what? Nothing. Forget I said anything. But then her phone lit up with Stephanie's name, and she turned it face down immediately. When I got home that night, Stephanie was already there. Her hair was all messed up and her lipstick was smeared on the wrong side of her mouth. How is Cassie? Good. It was Paul. Then she started telling me everything they did. The hotel room, the balcony, what they did against the wall. She kept getting louder with each detail. Stop, I told her. Why? Don't you wanna know? No. Her face got all twisted up. Well, I'm telling you anyway. She kept going with more details while I pulled out my phone and texted Cassie, thank you for a lovely evening. Stephanie saw my screen and threw her wine glass at the wall. It shattered everywhere, and I just stood there looking at her. The next week, I had to pick Cassie up because her car broke down. Out Of nowhere. Paul was supposed to drive me, she said, looking confused. I forgot at dinner. She had way too much wine. Can I tell you something? She asked, and her eyes looked glassy. Tuesday afternoons. That's when it started. My heart started racing. What started? She covered her mouth with her hand. Nothing. Forget it. But Tuesday was when Stephanie had mentioned the hotel and we both knew what she meant. Then we had to go to Stephanie's parents house for dinner. Stephanie showed up late and I could smell Paul's Cologne all over her clothes. Her mom noticed it right away and her face changed. Is that men's Cologne? The whole table went quiet. We're sharing partners with Cassie and Paul, I said. Every week. Her dad dropped his fork and it made this loud sound. Sharing? Taking turns dating each other's spouses. Stephanie's idea. Her mom stood up from the table in my house, she said, and her voice was shaking. Stephanie tried to explain, but everyone had already smelled the Cologne and knew what was happening. That night Cassie called me. I know about Tuesday afternoons. I felt sick to my stomach about them. I followed Paul once four months ago to the hotel. She sounded drunk. I saw everything. By week five, everything fell apart. It was Cassie's birthday and I threw her a surprise party, made a video of all her artwork and gave the speech about how talented and kind she was. Paul Forgot it was her birthday completely. I watched Stephanie watch Cassie cry happy tears and hold on to me like she didn't want to let go. That night, Stephanie came home from Paul's and started telling me what they did in graphic detail again. Stop! I don't want to hear it. She got mad. But I'm telling you everything. I didn't ask. Then she demanded to know what Cassie and I did together.
NA
NA

Wife confessed during a family dinner that she always wished she married my best friend. So I packed my things and left, but now she's begging me to come back. Last Sunday at my in law's house for their 30th anniversary dinner, everything seemed perfect. My wife Emma was helping her mom arrange flowers while I watched the game with her dad. My buddy Josh was there, too. He's been like family since college, always invited to everything. The whole extended family was there, maybe 20 people total. Emma's cousins, her weird Uncle Dave who likes vintage spoons. Her grandmother, who still asks when we're having kids even though we've been trying for three years. After dinner, her Aunt Linda starts this thing where everyone shares their sliding door moments. Those what if scenarios that keep you up at night. Everyone's going around the table sharing cute stories. Her cousin Sarah talks about almost moving to Japan to teach English. Uncle Dave mentions nearly buying Bitcoin in 2,010. Her brother Tom jokes about almost joining the military instead of becoming an accountant. Normal, harmless stuff that gets people thinking. Then it's Emma's turn. She's had a few glasses of wine, and she gets this dreamy, distant look in her eyes, like she's somewhere else entirely. Honestly, she says, looking directly at Josh across the table, I sometimes think I should have dated Josh instead of Mark back in college. We just click so naturally, you know, the entire table goes Dead silent. Her dad literally chokes on his coffee and starts coughing violently. Her mom drops her fork with a loud clatter. Her grandmother's mouth falls open. I'm sitting right there like a complete idiot, watching my wife of eight years fantasize about my best friend in front of our entire family. Josh's face goes bright red. He starts stammering something about how that's not appropriate. But Emma just keeps going like she's in some kind of trance. I mean, we have so much more in common than Mark and I. I do. Josh actually listens when I talk about my art projects. He gets my sense of humor. He remembers little things I say. Sometimes I wonder if I settled too quickly. That last part hit like a freight train. Settled? After eight years of marriage, two miscarriages, buying our first house together, and me working overtime to pay for her art supplies, I settled. I excused myself to the bathroom. But really, I just sat in my car for 20 minutes trying to process what had just happened. My hands were shaking. I called my brother Mike, but couldn't even form words to explain. When I came back inside, everyone was pretending nothing happened, making awkward small talk.
NA

How did you scam the scammer? Last Tuesday, I was making lunch for my kids when my phone rang. Unknown number, but I picked up anyway. Big mistake, right? This guy with a thick accent starts telling me he's from the IRS and I owe $4,200 in back taxes. As if I don't pay immediately with gift cards, the police will arrest me within an hour. Now, here's the thing. I literally just got my tax refund two weeks ago. My accountant, Beth, handled everything perfectly and I even got money back. So I knew this dude was full of it. But instead of hanging up, something clicked in my brain. My neighbour, Missus Kim, had fallen for this exact scam last month and lost $800. Time for payback. I started crying into the phone, oh, no, I can't go to jail. My kids need me. The scammer ate it up. He told me to go to target and buy iTunes gift cards worth $2,000 as a first payment. I said I needed an hour to get the money together. First, I called my cousin, Jake, who's a cop, told him what was happening and he said to keep the guy on the line as long as possible. Then I started my revenge tour. I called the scammer back an hour later sobbing. I'm at target, but I'm so confused. Which gift cards do I buy? He walked me through it step by step. I pretended to be this helpless Single mom who didn't understand technology. Sorry, can you repeat that? My hands are shaking so bad. For the next 20 minutes, I wandered around target asking him questions. Do I need the physical cards or the digital ones? The cashier is asking for ID is that normal? Sorry, my 4 year old is having a meltdown in the cart. Finally, I told him I had the cards. He was so excited, probably thinking about his commission. I read him the first number. Okay, it starts with 5. Wait, is that a 5?

But then Christmas rolled around, and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her co worker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. She showed me his Instagram. Tall, brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem? He didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby, and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed after that first dinner. My mom kept inviting him back. Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand, asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. You ever just realize someone who used to be your whole world is now just someone you used to know? Like no big fall out, no drama, just slowly stop talking, stop checking in, stop being us. And you sit there wondering when it happened, like what was the moment? What did I miss? How did we go from daily convos and inside jokes to seen and silence? And the worst part, I still care. I still see stuff and think they'd laugh at this or I wish I could tell them this, but I don't cause now it feel weird. Sad how people become strangers with memories. I can reach out, I can say something, but deep down I know if they wanted to talk to me, they would have. And I'm tired of always being the one holding the glue. So I just sit with it, act like I'm over it, pretend like losing people I never thought I'd lose is normal now. Whatever. People come and go, right? But fuck some of them. I really wanted to stay. What toxic family tradition did you break that cost you everything? In my family, December 3rd is off limits. No one is born on it, no one dies on it. No celebrations, no gatherings, no flights, no weddings, no trips. It's circled in thick red ink on every calendar in every relative's house. Growing up, it was just the day. If you asked why, you got a cold look and a quick we don't talk about December 3rd. I assumed it was just a creepy superstition. My cousins and I used to joke that it was the day someone sold their soul or bury gold or something equally ridiculous. But the adults, they didn't laugh. Ever. When I turned 28, I was engaged to the love of my life, Harper. She was funny, brilliant, and absolutely not into weird family rules. I didn't bring up the whole December 3rd thing until we started planning our wedding. Turns out the only date available at our dream venue was. Yep, December 3rd. I hesitated, not because I believed in any of it, but because I could already hear my mom's voice in my head. Over my dead body. Harper looked at me and said, do you actually believe anything will happen? No, I admitted, but my family will freak. So we did what rational adults do. We eloped. Quiet ceremony. Close friends, no one announcements. We figured we'd have a bigger party later and just say it was on a different date. We even posted the Photos on December 4th to avoid triggering anyone. Holy shit, what is wrong with September? It's only been 11 days and the world is completely off its fucking Rocker. Charlie Kirk was killed in front of his family, David was found with a body in his car, a Ukrainian girl was stabbed on the subway, and now Elon Musk isn't even the richest man on the planet anymore. Can we chill for one second? First, Charlie Kirk got shot during a speech in Utah. He was literally in front of his wife and kids when a bullet entered his artery through his neck. The scene was so bloody and gruesome it's insane. A Ukrainian girl gets stabbed on a train in Charlotte. She escaped a literal war, came here to be safe, and still got killed because this planet has zero peace. Then D4D has a whole body in his car. Like, not a metaphorical one, an actual human body in a bag in his trunk. And this dude just casually performed like he didn't have a horror movie in his backseat. What the hell? And even outside all of that, Elon Musk is no longer the richest person in the world, losing his top spot to a rival tech CEO, showing how unstable everything feels right now, even at the highest levels. It's like every time I open my phone, reality speed runs another tragedy. Like, bro, it's been 11 days. September just started. I thought my only problem this month would be math class, but no, apparently it's Full blown world collapse. Society isn't just cooked, it's burnt to ash.

Guys, y'all do not know how annoying it is to be colorblind. Like, you're just chilling with your friends, and then you tell them, or they find out that you're colorblind, they will begin to ask the dumbest question, like, what color is my shirt? Or what color is the grass? Like, your shirt is purple. And then they say, no, it's blue. Like, bro, it isn't my fault that I didn't know that because I see purple. And then as soon as they know it, they'll tell their friends, like, bro, did you know he's colorblind? And then in one second, everyone comes and asks me questions. And then there is that one time I was with a friend, we got out of the store, and I see a purple bicycle with green wheels. So I say, bro, what is that combination, bro? Like, purple and green? And then he says, bro, that's blue. And I say, no. And then he calls an old man and says, sir, that bicycle is blue, right? And that gentleman says, yes, and then he says, well, that guy says it's purple. Or one time I saw someone drawing with gray, and I asked him, dude, why are you coloring with gray? And he says, uh, bro, it's dark green.

Man, the one fucking day my dad don't go to work, everything goes straight to hell. I wake up feeling good as shit, thinking I got the house to myself. I go downstairs, ready to make some cereal, and boom, this man already sitting at the table with a mug, staring at me like I just committed a fucking crime. Oh, so you just wake up at noon now? Bro, it's 10:30. Chill. Then he hits me with the classic, since I'm home today, we're gonna get some stuff done around here that we ain't fooling nobody. He mean me. Next thing I know, I'm cleaning the dusty ass garage, holding a flashlight while he trying to fix some shit that's been broken since Obama was in office. And of course, I'm getting yelled at for not doing it right, even though he ain't tell me Jack. I try to sneak back into my room, throw my headphones on, maybe catch a break. This man kicks the door open like the damn SWAT team. Why the fuck you on your phone? Go clean the yard. The yard? Bro, it's 95 degrees. The sun beating my ass like it's personal. Every time I sit down for 2 seconds, he pops up with, back in my day, we didn't have time to sit. Back in your day, y'all didn't have Wi-Fi or air conditioning either? This ain't the damn 80s. Let me chill. Finally, by the time he done dragging me through The surprise boot camp. He sits on the couch like a proud general and hits me with, wasn't that a productive day? No, it was a fucking nightmare. I didn't sign up for this unpaid labor. Moral of the story, if your dad's off work, you better fake sleep, hide in the basement, or disappear altogether. Cause once he hits you with that get stuff done bullshit, your peace is done.

Did you convince your parents to remove your bedtime rule? My brother saved our entire house because he refused to sleep. We had the strictest bedtime rule of any family I knew. Nine PM meant lights out, no exceptions, no matter what. Had projects or homework finish before 9, exams study before 9, gaming with friends? Definitely before 9. It didn't bother me much because I was 7, but it affected my brother a lot. He told me how he felt left out sometimes because his friends constantly texted about late night shows and online game he'd never see. My brother was the only eighth grader who had to be in bed before fourth graders. Growing bodies need 10 hours of sleep. Mom and dad would say nothing good happens after 9 anyway. But my brother tried everything to change their minds. He offered to get straight A's in exchange change for a 10:30 bedtime. He showed them studies about how teens only need five hours of sleep to function well compared to kids and adults, but they still refused. When you're 18, you can destroy your sleep schedule all you want. My brother looked heartbroken. 18 was so far off and by then he'd be too old to enjoy it. That's when my brother became an expert at fake sleeping. He Learned to lie completely still with his eyes shut, breathing so evenly that mom's flashlight checks never caught him. He could hear footsteps on the stairs from two Rooms away and transform from wide awake to dead asleep in two seconds. After the ten PM inspection, he'd wait exactly 20 minutes for our parents to pour their wine and start their TV shows. He made me promise never to tell. In exchange, he'd let me stay up too sometimes with him. It was like our own secret midnight meetings and our parents never really caught on. They ended up bragging to everyone about how well we listen to their rules. But then one day my brother got cornered into a wall and was left.

My fiance told me to leave if I didn't like her lifestyle. So I left. I was looking at credit card statements last month when my fiance Bianca was packing for another girl's trip, her fourth this year. We need to talk about these trips. I said. This Miami one will cost at least $3,000. That's 12,000 this year alone. She rolled her eyes. I work hard. I deserve fun. The thing was I covered all our expenses, rent, utilities, groceries, her car payment. Her entire salary was play money. You spend your whole income on trips while I cover everything else. I pointed out my trips are non negotiable. She said, you don't like it, then leave. She said it so casually like our five year relationship meant nothing. Fine. I said I'll leave. She laughed over a girl's trip? Seriously? Over you telling me to leave rather than discuss our finances like adults. Yeah. She grabbed her suitcase from Miami without even saying goodbye. I called my brother. Still have that empty room, started packing immediately. While packing, found receipts from her Vegas trip, bottle service, VIP sections and a 500 dollar receipt from a men's clothing store. Who buys men's clothes on a girl's trip. Next morning, removed her as authorized user on my credit cards. By Saturday, 47 missed calls from her friends in Miami. Her card got declined. Sunday she texted, my cards are maxed. I'm stranded. Use your own cards. I replied, that's financial Abuse. This is me leaving like you suggested. Monday I went to our apartment early, packed all my stuff, took everything I bought, TV, gaming console, coffee maker, even the good shower head. Left her designer clothes and makeup. Left a note as suggested, I've left rents paid through months end. After that, it's your responsibility. Also left, print out showing 47,000 thousand dollars spent on girls trips over three years, almost a house down payment. She exploded by a text, you took the TV. Are you 12? This is theft. Then pivoted to, please let's talk. I'm sorry. Showed up at my office, had security escort her out. Posted on Instagram about toxic men who can't handle independent women. Comments weren't what she expected. Independent? Don't you live in his apartment? Maybe he got tired of funding your lifestyle. She deleted it within an hour. Week later, she emailed, I can't afford the apartment. My cards are maxed. Parents think I'm irresponsible. Please come home. I'll cancel the next.

I kicked my family off my Amazon plan. So my whole family had been using my Amazon Prime account for like three years. My mom, my sister Ashley, my Uncle Rick. Even my grandma somehow figured out how to order stuff. I was paying for it because I actually use Amazon all the time for work stuff and groceries, but they were just leeching off it. The breaking point happened two weeks ago. I check my account and see 17 packages coming to different addresses. 17! My sister ordered a whole workout set she'll never use. My mom got some fancy face cream that cost 60 bucks, and my Uncle Rick ordered a drone he definitely doesn't need. But the worst part was my cousin Blake ordered a gaming chair that cost $400. I called Blake and asked him what the hell he was thinking. He just laughed and said it's not his problem. I gave everyone access. He said if I didn't want people using it, I shouldn't have shared the password. This kid just graduated high school and acts like he runs the world. So I called my mom and told her everyone needed to chip in for prime or get their own accounts. She got all dramatic and said family should help each other out. She reminded me how she used to buy me clothes when I was younger. I told her that was literally her job as a parent and not the same thing at all. Then Ashley calls me crying, saying she can't afford her own prime account because she's saving for a wedding. I reminded her that her wedding is in two years, and she just spent $300 on workout clothes she turned last month. She said I was being petty and that it's only like $10 a month split between everyone. I did the math. If everyone chipped in 10 bucks, that would actually cover prime and give me extra money. But when I suggested this in our family group chat, suddenly everyone had excuses. My mom said she's on a fixed income. Ashley said she's saving for the wedding. Rick said he barely uses it anyway, which is a lie because he ordered protein powder just yesterday. The final straw was when my grandma called me, confused about why her soap order got canceled. Turns out my account got flagged for suspicious activity. Because there were so many different addresses, Amazon temporarily locked my account and I couldn't order my medication.

The thing about trios is that no matter how hard you try, you're always going to end up feeling like the outsider. It's like being right there, sitting with them, but still invisible. You laugh when they laugh, but deep down you know you're laughing at something you weren't even part of. You watch them get closer and closer, and you start questioning yourself, like, what's wrong with me? Why am I never enough to be chosen? It's the kind of hurt that doesn't scream. It just sits heavy in your chest until you feel like breaking. And the worst part is, you can pour your heart out, you can beg them to understand, but nothing changes. They keep being a duo, and you keep being the leftover. That's when it hits you. You deserve better than fighting for scraps of attention. You deserve friends who make you feel like you belong, who don't make you wonder if you're the problem. It's so hard to let go. But sometimes you have to. Because staying in that kind of pain is worse than being alone.

Why is math class easy but the exam feels like squid game? Like, math teachers will tell you that the exam is going to be easy, next thing you know, question 1 looks like it was written by NASA. Bro, I came here for algebra, not to calculate rocket fuel. And in class they're giving us baby problems. Like if Johnny has two apples and gives away one, how much apples will he have? Bro, on the exam it's if Johnny invests his apples at a 7% return while traveling at the speed of light, how many apples does he have left in a black hole? What? Where was that in the notes? And the best part is when they say if anyone has doubts, ask me. So one kid actually raises his hand like um, I don't get No. 3 and instead of helping, the teacher goes full roast mode. You don't know this? We literally just did this yesterday. Bro, he asked for help, not a public execution. And they'll hit you with damn is just like the homework. Yeah right. The homework was 2 + 2. The exam is proof why 2 + 2 = 4 using 18 pages of logic. When it's finally over, they smile and go see? It wasn't that hard. Bro, that wasn't an exam. That was a boss fight. And I walked in with no armor, no weapons, and half a health bar.

So apparently, even escaping a war zone doesn't guarantee safety anymore. A 23 year old Ukrainian woman moved to the United States for a better life, only to lose it in the most tragic way on a train in Charlotte. Her name was Irina. She was just heading home after work, wearing her pizza shop T-shirt, AirPods in, minding her own business like everybody else on that train. But sitting right behind her was a man in a red hoodie, restless, agitated. And within minutes, he pulled out a knife and attacked her, completely unprovoked. She never even saw it coming. The man, the Carlos Brown, wasn't some random first time offender. He had a long history of violent crime and mental illness. He'd already served prison time, and he wasn't even supposed to be on that train because he didn't have a ticket. Yet somehow, he was there. And because of that, a young woman who just wanted safety ended up losing her life. Other passengers who witnessed it said they're traumatized. And honestly, who wouldn't be? You're just commuting home, and suddenly something unthinkable happens right in front of you. This story is more than a headline. It's a reminder of how fragile life really is. Rant signing off.

I don't know how to explain it, but I really love people who make sure I don't feel left out. Like, it's the little things, when they slide me into the conversation or when they make sure I'm included in the plans. It just means so much. It makes you feel like you actually matter to them. And that feeling, that's something I'll never take for granted. Well, anyways, thanks. Out. Mwah.

You know what? I love people who don't make me feel like an option. Like it feels so different when someone actually chooses you, you know, not just when they're bored or when it's easy, but because they really want you there. It shows in the little things, when they check in, when they make time, when they make you feel like you actually matter. And that feeling, that's the kind of thing that sticks with you. Well, anyways, VEX out. Mwah.

Do you ever notice how comforting it is when someone just matches your energy? Like if you're laughing at something stupid, they're right there laughing with you. If you're tired or quiet, they don't make it weird. They just vibe with you. It's such a safe feeling knowing you don't have to perform or explain yourself. They just get it. Well, anyways, VEX out. Mwah.

My teacher just accused me of using AI. I was just chilling in class when he suddenly put someone's essay on the projector and says, whose is this? I start reading through it and I'm like, oh my god, that's mine. He's about to give me an award or something. So I raise my hand all confident and go, yeah, that's mine. And he looks at me and goes, are you sure? Like, bro, yes, I'm sure. I literally finished writing it at 3:00am last night. So I say, yeah, I'm completely sure. And he goes, okay, see me after class. Now this is at the start of class. So the next 40 minutes everyone is just staring at me while I'm stressing out. Finally class ends and I walk up to him like, hey, that's my essay. I'm actually pretty proud of it. He pulls it up on his computer, points to an em dash and says, what's this right here? I tell him that's an em dash. And then he snaps, cuts me off mid sentence and says, don't play smart with me. You didn't write this. You used AI. And if you think I'm letting that slide, you're dead wrong. You'll explain yourself to the principal tomorrow because as of right now, you failed this class. I tried explaining everything to him, even showing proof I wrote it, but he just wasn't listening, bro. I walked out of there with tears in my eyes and now I've Got a meeting with the principal tomorrow morning, guys. What should I do?
NA

Men who proposed and she said no. What happened afterwards with your life? I've been dating Sophia for four years when I finally decided to ask the big question. Her parents treated me like their own son, especially after they found out I grew up in foster care. Her little brother would literally follow me around their house, begging me to teach him how to fix engines. Someone who never had a real family, being part of theirs felt like everything I've been missing my whole life. I've been saving every extra dollar from my job at Murphy's Auto Shop for months. The ring wasn't fancy, just a simple band with a small diamond, but it was real and it was all I could afford. I planned everything perfectly. Sophia's dad was turning 60 and they were throwing this big backyard BBQ. All her family would be there, plus her closest friends. She always said family was the most important thing to her. So I figured proposing surrounded by everyone who loved us both would be perfect. The party was going great. Sophia's mom made her famous brisket. Her dad was telling embarrassing stories about Sophia as a kid. And everyone was laughing and having a good time. After they brought out the birthday cake and saying happy birthday, I figured it was the perfect moment. My hands were shaking as I tapped my beer bottle with a fork to get everyone's attention. The whole backyard went dead silent. Sophia Looked confused at first, then her eyes went wide. When I got down on one knee and pulled out the ring box, her mom gasped and started tearing up. Her dad had this huge smile on his face. Her friends were already pulling out their phones to record the moment. I opened the box and said all the things I've been practicing in my head for weeks, how much I loved her, how she changed my life, how I wanted to spend forever making her happy. The words just poured out of me. But Sophia just stood there frozen, not good, frozen like she was overwhelmed with happiness. Bad frozen like she'd seen a ghost. Liam, she finally said, and I could hear the panic in her voice, I love you so much, but I'm not ready for this. I'm so sorry. The silence that followed was the worst sound I'd ever heard, 30 people just staring at us, not knowing what to do or where to look. I stayed on one knee for probably five seconds too long, trying to process what had just happened. Then I slowly stood up, shoved the ring box back in my pocket and nodded. Okay, I said, because what else could I say? Sophia reached for my arm, but I stepped back. I couldn't deal with her trying to comfort me in front of everyone. I mumbled something about needing to go and walked straight to my truck. The drive home was the Longest 20 minutes of my life. I stayed up all night staring at the ceiling, replaying every conversation we'd ever had about the future. We talked about getting married, about kids, about buying a house together. How had I read everything so wrong? Next day I was under the hood of a broken down Chevy trying to lose myself in work when I heard footsteps approaching. I looked up expecting to see my boss, but it was so.

A man at the art gallery told me I couldn't possibly understand the painting in front of us. I painted it. I was standing in front of my largest piece at the gallery opening, champagne in hand, when a man in an expensive suit approached and started explaining my own painting to me. He had no idea I was the artist because the placard said Riley Turner, who he clearly assumed was a man since he kept talking about his brilliant technique. This guy, Robert, looked me up and down and said, you seem young to be at an opening like this. Let me guess. Looking for a rich boyfriend, smart girl, lots of wealthy men here. He gestured at my painting like he owned it. See, what Riley is doing here requires years of training to appreciate. You probably just think the colors are pretty. The average woman just sees decoration. I took a sip of champagne and said, interesting perspective, which I guess he took as encouragement. Robert moved closer to the painting, physically stepping in front of me and continued his lecture. A girl like you probably thinks this is just nice to look at, but there's actual intelligence behind it. The artist is obviously a man because women simply don't have this kind of technical mastery. Female painters do flowers and feelings. This has real intellectual depth. It's biological, really. Men are just more capable of this level of abstraction. When I mentioned I was familiar, With the artist's work, Robert laughed and patted my shoulder. Following him on Instagram to look at the pretty pictures doesn't count as being familiar with art, sweetheart. You probably think you're cultured because you went to that Van Gogh light show. Real knowledge comes from decades of study, not whatever you Learned from TikTok. Robert decided to test me, rapid firing questions. Who's basket? What's Kiara Scuro? Name three Renaissance painters besides da Vinci. When I started to answer, he cut me off. Wrong. See, this is why galleries shouldn't have open events. You probably googled some terms before coming here to impress men. But Riley here is working in a tradition you couldn't possibly understand without a proper education. Not community college, sweetie, real universities. He returned to my painting now explaining it louder to draw a crowd. What Riley has achieved here would cost probably 100,000 in education to even attempt. The materials alone cost more than you'd make in a month at whatever retail job you have. He looked at my outfit with disgust. Target clearance rack, right? Someone who shops there couldn't possibly grasp the investment in this piece. Probably spent more on one brush than your entire outfit. When I suggested the artist might be self taught, Robert sneered at me. Is that how you Learned about art? Painting parties? Robert grabbed my wrist to pull me to another angle. His grip too tight. You're too stupid to even stand in the right spot. Riley intended for this to be viewed from exactly here. Your ignorance is actually disrespectful to his work. He kept his hand on my wrist while explaining, though honestly, explaining this to you is like teaching calculus to a toddler. You lack the basic foundation to understand any of it. He noticed me trying to pull away and.

Did your family realize you weren't a little kid anymore? I'm 23 and my family still cuts my food for me at restaurants. Not kidding. My mom will literally reach over and slice my chicken into bite size pieces while I'm eating it. Growing up as the youngest of seven kids by a huge gap didn't help. My siblings are all 10, 15 years older than me. So they've always treated me like their living doll at family dinners. They still ask if I need help tying my shoes or if I remembered to brush my teeth. My sister Amanda still tries to help me order at restaurants, telling in servers she'll have the chicken nuggets without asking what I want. Last month at my cousin Abigail's wedding was the absolute worst. The whole extended family was there, aunts, uncles, grand, grandparents, great aunts, family, friends. The worst, during cocktail hour, my Aunt Janet loudly announced that I couldn't have champagne because babies don't drink alcohol. She handed me a juice box instead. A juice box at a wedding? I'm 23 years old with a medical degree. Then came dinner seating. My Uncle Mark grabbed my arm and said, come on, sweetie, you're sitting at the kids table. I tried to protest, explaining I was an adult, but he was already walking me over to a table full of actual children. Eight year olds coloring on placemats. Ten year olds playing with action figures and me with my college degree. And my job that none of them bothered asking about. The kids kept asking me questions like what grade are you in and do you like our coloring books? I spent the entire dinner helping a six year old nephew cut his chicken while my family laughed from the adult tables, pointing and taking photos like it was cute. My cousin Kelly walked over during appetizers. Ah, look at you helping the little ones, she cooed. Maybe someday you'll be ready for grown up conversations. She patted my head like I was a golden retriever. The breaking point came during cake cutting. When the bride and groom finished their ceremonial first slice, they started serving guests. My Uncle Mark walked over with a plate and a plastic fork. A plastic fork. Let me help you with this, honey, he said, and started cutting my slice into tiny little pieces like I was a toddler who might choke. Uncle Mark, I can careful with the fork, sweetie. He interrupted, taking it from my hands. We don't want any accidents. Remember what happened at Christmas when you tried to use the good silverware? I haven't dropped anything at Christmas. He was just making stuff up. The entire reception was staring at this point. Other guests were whispering and pointing. Some were filming with their phones. I felt my face burning with embarrassment. That's when the bridesmaid of honor walked over. She was this elegant woman in her 40s looking confused. Excuse me. Are you Doctor Nguyen? She asked, staring directly at me. Everyone at nearby tables turned to look. My Aunt Janet burst out laughing like this was the funniest thing she'd ever heard. Oh, honey, that's just our baby cousin, she said condescendingly. She's still figuring out college classes and living in the dorms, playing dress up as a doctor. Aren't you, sweetie? The woman's face went from confused to absolutely shocked. Ma'am, this is Doctor Nguyen. She performed emergency brain surgery on my six year old daughter.
NA

Have you ever been asked to explain your ankle monitor at Disney World? The Disney princess stopped mid autograph, stared at my ankle, then at my six year old daughter, Emma, then back at my ankle. Sir, is that. She started clearly breaking character, which apparently requires something serious at the happiest place on earth. It's not what you think, I said quickly, but Cinderella was already flagging security. Within minutes, I was surrounded by three guards and mouse ear hats trying to look threatening, while tourists took photos of what they assumed was part of the show. Here's the thing. I'm not a criminal. The ankle monitor was court ordered, but not for the reason everyone assumes. My ex wife, Patricia, claimed I was a flight risk during our custody battle. Said I might take Emma to Brazil because I'd renewed my passport. I renewed it for a work conference in Toronto. Judge still ordered the monitor as a precaution until custody was finalized. I've been wearing it for three months, setting off every metal detector in Orange County. Emma didn't understand why Cinderella looked scared. Daddy, why is the princess sad? I knelt down, ankle monitor clicking against the pavement. She's just confused about daddy's special bracelet. Security moved closer. One spoke into his radio. We have a code yellow in fantasy land. I didn't know what that meant, but it sounded bad. Tourists and pulling their kids away from us. One mom loudly whispered, that's why we Check the registry, Karen. The head of security, a surprisingly intimidating man named Raul, escorted us to Disney Jail. Yes, that's a real thing. It's a small office behind Main Street that smells like churros and broken dreams. Emma thought it was a VIP experience. Are we getting special Mickey ears? She asked. Raul pulled up my information on his computer. His expression shifted from suspicious to confused to sympathetic. Like custody battle? He asked quietly. I nodded. He sighed. My brother went through the same thing. Judge made him wear one for six months because his ex said he'd flee to Cuba. He's never even been to Cuba. Raul made some calls. Twenty minutes later, we had a Disney escort. Not because I was dangerous, but because Raul felt bad. No kids should have their Disney trip ruined by adult problems, he said. Our escort, Jerome, was a former NBA player who'd retired to work at Disney because he loved making kids happy. Emma rode on his shoulders the entire day. We, every line, got front row seats to every show. Jerome told everyone I was a special guest, which technically wasn't a lie. The ankle monitor kept setting off the sensors on rides. Space Mountain stopped three times because of me. They had to manually override the system. By the third ride, the operators knew me by name. Ankle monitor dad is back, they'd radio ahead. It became a running joke. One operator said, you know, we've had Weapons, drugs, even a snake once. But you're our first ankle monitor. I chose to take that as an achievement. Plot twist came at dinner. We were at the character meal when goofy sat down at our table. He pointed at my ankle, then did an elaborate MIME of being arrested, going to court, then being innocent. Emma laughed hysterically. Goofy's silly daddy. But then goofy pulled out his phone.

I asked my brother not to bring his girlfriend to my wedding. My brother Jake has this girlfriend named Becca who literally cannot stand not being the centre of attention for five minutes. Every family dinner, every holiday, every gathering, she finds a way to make it about her. Last Thanksgiving, she announced she was pregnant right when my dad was about to carve the Turkey. Turns out she wasn't even pregnant. Just wanted to see everyone's reactions. So when I was planning my wedding to my fiance Ryan, I knew I had to do something about the Becca situation. This was going to be my one day. The one day that was supposed to be about me and Ryan starting our life together. I called Jake about three months before the wedding. Hey, so about the wedding I started. I need to ask you something kind of awkward. What's up? He said, and I could hear him eating cereal in the background. I really don't want Becca there. I know that sounds harsh, but she always makes everything about herself, and I just can't deal with that stress. On my wedding day, the line went quiet for, like, 10 seconds, and Jake exploded. Are you serious right now? You're uninviting my girlfriend from your wedding? I'm not uninviting her because she was never invited in the first place. The invitation was just for you. That's the same thing. We've been together for two years. He's basically family. I tried To explain that it wasn't personal, that I just wanted one drama free day. But Jake wasn't having it. He said if Becca couldn't come, then he wouldn't come either. I told him that was his choice, hoping he'd change his mind. He didn't. But here's where it gets crazy. The day of my wedding, I'm getting my makeup done in the bridal suite when my cousin Madison bursts in. Uh, you need to see this, she says, shoving her phone in my face. It's Becca's Instagram story. She's posted, like, 15 videos of herself getting all dressed up, doing her makeup, picking out jewellery. The caption on the last one says, can't wait to celebrate love today. With a bunch of heart emojis and the location tagged as our wedding venue. My heart drops. He's coming anyway. Madison nods. Jake's outside right now, arguing with your dad about it. He says he changed his mind and decided to bring her. I'm standing there in my wedding dress, half my makeup done, and I have to deal with.

How do I tell my crush I fell in love with her kids? I found my work crush share crying in the break room, looking completely stressed. My dad's in the hospital and I need to fly out tonight, but I can't find anyone to watch my kids. My ex won't answer, the babysitter I hired bailed, and I just. I can't afford to miss this flight, but I can't afford anything else either. She leaned against my shoulder, crying even harder. I volunteered without thinking. I'll watch them, I said, heart racing from how close she was to me. Are you serious? It's three kids. Three for at least two weeks. I waved my hand around like a lovesick fool. How hard can it be? The kids showed up at my apartment that night with tons of suitcases. The oldest, around 14, looked at her mom and said, really? Another boyfriend? Cher's face went red. He's just a friend from work. Camilla. The middle one, 10, rolled his eyes. The youngest, seven, wouldn't even look at me, stood in my doorway like they were being sentenced to prison. Cher hug them quickly told them to be good, and left for the airport. I stood there with three kids who clearly hated me and realized I was in way over my head. The first morning, I woke up early to make them pancakes. When the oldest one, Camilla, laughed. She's not here, you know. You can stop trying, she said. Besides, you're not her type. Mom doesn't date guys without kids. We've seen this a dozen times already. It hurt, but it wasn't a lie. Cher's co workers, guys from her gym, men from dating apps. Everyone wanted to play dad until they realized three kids meant actual work. And the kids really didn't make it any easier. From spilling drinks on my laptop to turning the TV up during important zoom meetings, they hated every second with me. Dude, just survive until she gets back, then ask her out. My friend told me that became the plan. Survive two weeks, do whatever to keep the kids happy. Be the hero, finally land a date with share. But like most things, it doesn't always happen the way you want it to. Sometime within the second week, the middle kid, Murph, came home from school trying to hide a black eye. Before I could even ask, Camilla grabbed ice from the freezer and held it against his face. Just pretend you didn't see anything, she told me coldly. I bent down beside them and asked in a kind but stern voice, tell me what happened. Just leave me alone, he said, turning away. I shook my head. I'm not here to lecture you or get get mad at you or do anything without your permission. Not even tell your mom. But I need to know what happened. Murph blinked at me and frowned. Someone called me an orphan because I don't Have a dad! I patted his head and thanked him, walking away as calm as I could, even though all the blood in my body was boiling with anger. Next afternoon, I took a half day at work and showed up at their school in a rented GTR, strikingly white engine, purring like a monster. I rolled down the window and waved, wearing sunglasses and a black polo. Who's got the coolest dad now? I said loudly, as Murph and his friends ran over excitedly. Murph watched his bully's jaw drop and quickly hopped in. He rolled down the window and flipped him off, which was my signal to immediately drive off the middle school campus. Okay, I like the enthusiasm, but let's never tell your mother about this, I said, grinning. I picked up the other two kids and took them to in and out for a quick afternoon snack, then surprised them with a baseball game. Murph ate in a helmet full of nachos, and I managed to snag a foul ball for little Celia. Not bad, old man, Camilla said, watching her siblings enjoy the game. We made sure to take pics with the car and at the stadium, all covered in ketchup and mustard, sent everything to their mom with a caption we wish you were here. After that, things between me and the kids sort of changed. When the youngest, Celia, had a nightmare and called for her mom, I sat beside her bed reading Out fairy tales until she fell asleep. I made the kids meals and lunch box.
NA

Grandmother asked me, do you wear that bracelet I sent you every day? My stomach sank. What bracelet? She pulled out her phone and showed me a receipt. 3,000 dollar custom gold bracelet with your birthstone delivered four months ago. I'd never seen it in my life. My mom suddenly got very interested in her coffee cup. Dad started scrolling through his phone like nothing happened. The air in the restaurant felt thick with tension. Mom, I said slowly, did you sign for a package addressed to me? Her face went red. We thought it was a mistake. Grandma sends so many things. A mistake? Grandma's voice could cut glass. I had it engraved with his name. And track the delivery myself. I watched my parents exchange that look, the same guilty look they'd been giving each other for months whenever grandma brought up gifts or money. I thought I was being paranoid. But now everything was starting to make sense. Show me the tracking information. Dad interrupted, trying to sound authoritative. Grandma scrolled through her phone. Delivered to your front door on March 15th at two forty seven PM signed for by Leora Hensley. She looked directly at my mom. That's you, isn't it, Leora? My mom's hands started shaking. I, I don't remember every package that comes to the house. You don't remember a 3,000 dollar piece of jewelry? Grandma's eyebrows shot up. That's when I noticed my sister's new tennis bracelet sparkling on her wrist. The same design. The same stones, the same everything. My stomach dropped. I'd seen Alara wearing it for weeks, bragging to her friends about how she'd treated herself after getting good grades. Alara's idea of treating herself was usually a five dollar coffee, not luxury jewelry. Alara, I said, staring at her arm. Where did you get that? She yanked her sleeve down faster than I'd ever seen her move. I, um, saved up for it. Alara works part time at a smoothie shop making $12 an hour. She spends most of her paycheck on makeup and clothes. There was no way she had $3,000 saved. How long did you save? I pressed, feeling my anger building. Like a few months, she mumbled, not making eye contact. A few months of smoothie shop money bought you a 3,000 dollar bracelet. Mom jumped in. Alara has been very responsible with her money lately. Really? I turned to my parents because last month she asked me for $20 for gas money. The month before that, she needed $50 for textbooks. Just last week she was complaining about being broke. Dad cleared his throat. Lauren, you're being dramatic. Maybe Alara got a bonus or from a smoothie shop. I cut him off. Alara, what's the most expensive thing you've ever bought with your own money? She fidgeted with her napkin. I don't know, maybe my phone case, which cost like $30. The math wasn't mathing and everyone at the table knew it. Grandma leaned forward her Eyes locked on Alara's bracelet. Show me that bracelet now. I don't wanna take it off, Alara said, her voice getting smaller. It might fall.

Bro, everybody's got that one disrespectful demon friend in class who simply cannot handle serious shit. Like we'll be sitting there minding our business, and the teacher suddenly drops a bomb like, my aunt passed away this morning. Whole class goes silent. Shit gets colder than a funeral home in Antarctica. And just as everyone's processing it respectfully, here go this bitch sitting next to me biting their lip, cheeks puffed up like a balloon, trying to hold in the most disrespectful giggle of all time. You look over and this fools got their hoodie pulled up, shaking violently like they got hit with a damn Taser, wheezing like a broken vacuum. And this disrespectful bastard keeps whispering, bro, imagine she died trying to twerk. I almost threw my chair. Meanwhile, the teachers up front with tears in her eyes, clutching a picture frame. And we over here looking like we trying to survive an exorcism. He still has the nerve to say, damn, she dead. Dead. At this point, my stomach is making satanic noises. I'm squeezing my legs so tight trying to hold in this demon fart that I might have caused a blood clot. But that's not even the worst part. The teacher starts showing a slideshow of her aunt, like a full ass memorial Powerpoint. And this motherfucker goes, why she look like a GTA character on slide 3? I look at him like, you going to hell and dragging me with you?

If you have a skin color other than white or speak a language other than English, the immigration police today got permission from the Supreme Court and Donald Trump to arrest you, throw you in jail for a couple days and check on your citizenship and green card. If you're here legally, you'll probably be let go and will probably be fired from your job because you were out of contact for multiple days. There was a decision made by the Supreme Court today that says it is okay for the immigration police to surround large groups of people and take all of them to jail. Normally, the Supreme Court has to give some sort of explanation for this type of decision. In this case, it did not give any explanation. Normally, the Supreme Court members that made the decision have to sign their names to the order. In this case, they did not sign their names to the order. Lower courts had placed significant restrictions on Trump's efforts to ramp up immigration arrests, but now the Supreme Court says no restrictions.

My brother got me kicked out. Now my he wants my house. When I was 16, my gaming obsessed brother Tyler convinced my parents I was taking up too much space in our cramped three bedroom apartment. He'd been complaining for months that he needed my room for his elaborate gaming setup. My parents sat me down one evening and basically said I had two weeks to find alternative living arrangements. The reasoning? I was almost 17, practically an adult, and Tyler needed space to pursue his passion in gaming and dreaming. They genuinely believed he was going to become the next big Twitch star. I was devastated, but had nowhere to go. My girlfriend Emma's parents noticed I'd been spending more time at their house and eventually asked what was going on. When I explained the situation, her mom immediately said I could stay stay with them as long as I needed, no questions asked. Emma and I got serious fast. Living under the same roof will do that to a relationship. When we turned 19, I proposed with a ring. I'd saved six months for working overtime every weekend. Her parents were thrilled. They basically raised me for two years anyway and considered me their son. At 23, we finally had enough saved for a down payment on a small two bedroom house. Nothing fancy. We spent every weekend renovating, learning YouTube tutorials, making mistakes and fixing them. Meanwhile, Tyler was still living with my parents in his Gaming paradise. He dropped out of community college after one semester, claiming his streaming career was about to take off. College was just holding him back. Three years later, he was still grinding away at maybe five viewers on a good day. Sleeping until two PM, gaming until 4:00am. Ordering Doordash with my parents money. My parents occasionally texted generic holiday messages or shared Facebook posts about family, but otherwise we had zero relationship. Last month my mom showed up at my house completely unannounced. I hadn't seen her.

This world is truly fucking evil if you don't know what's going on. Charlie Kirk just got shot in the neck. Simple as that. He's a conservative. He's a Christian. You know, all he did was debate people. He never hurt anyone. He always made sure everything was light hearted and fun, talking about LeBron James and Michael Jordan and shit like that. And he, he was never, he, he's not a bad guy. I'm not gonna get into my political views because I'm not trying to lose a platform. But I think truly there is no possible justification for what happened to him. You guys see him in the fucking TikToks or whatever talking to whoever, but you don't know he has a family he goes home to, he has two, he has two daughters that are toddlers. He has a wife. He has a parent. He has parents. Like he has a family. And you guys are willing to take away his life because you disagree with what he says. I'm not trying to stretch it, but he's, he's literally a modern day MLK. Like he's an activist. Okay. I'm like, I'm so dead ass. I'm so serious. This is like an actual horrible situation. He was truly a puppet of God. And, and he did so much good for the world, even though people like couldn't see it. And even if you disagree, there's no reason to take someone's life. Like there was kids, not that audience. There was women, there was men, there was, it's just breathtaking. This world truly needs more Christ. And please keep his family and him in your prayers.

My husband punched my pregnant sister in the stomach and thank god he did. My husband walked up to my 8 months pregnant sister during her baby shower and punched her full force in the stomach. She folded in half and crashed backward into the gift table. While 50 guests screamed, I shoved him backward screaming, what is wrong with you? While my mom called 9 1 1, sobbing about assault on a pregnant woman. My dad and brothers pinned my husband against the wall and I was hitting his chest, calling him a psychopath while my sister lay on the floor holding her belly and crying that something was wrong. Her boyfriend was checking for blood and everyone was filming while my grandmother was having chest pains from the shock. My aunts grabbed their kids and ran while I dropped beside my sister trying to feel the baby kick, but she kept pushing my hands away saying don't touch, it hurts too much. The neighbor who was a midwife tried to come help, but my sister curled into a ball screaming not to touch her stomach. My uncle was on the phone with his lawyer saying we needed to press charges for attempted murder of an unborn child. While my sister's mother in law fainted and had to be laid on the couch, my sister kept her arms wrapped around her stomach so tight nobody could get close, crying that she could feel something was wrong inside. Look at Her stomach where I hit her, my has been yelled while fighting against the men holding him and I wanted to kill him until I saw it, a deep dent in my sister's belly that wasn't popping back out. That's memory foam under her dress, not a baby. And I can prove everything she's been doing. I got to my sister before she could stop me and felt around the dent. My hands went numb pressing against foam edges and Velcro straps where my nephew should have been. She's been buying different sized fake bellies online to fake the progression, stealing ultrasound photos from pregnancy forums and photoshopping her name on them and scamming everyone for $30,000 in medical bills for appointments that never existed because I checked with every OB in the city. I kept pressing on the dented foam while my sister tried to push me away and everyone started grabbing at her stomach, finding more straps and padding underneath. I followed her after she said she had an OB appointment yesterday and she went to a bar and drank for two hours, then bought three more fake bellies at a costume shop downtown. My sister was crying.

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favorite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.

Genuinely, what is going on this week? There has been a school shooting in Denver. A girl got stabbed on the subway and no one helped her. A decomposing body found in D4V D's car. A man was beheaded at Dallas motel. Charlie Kirk getting shot and killed at a university. And all on top of that, the 9 11 was 24 years ago today. As much as I hate Charlie Kirk and his decisions, no one deserves to get killed. Imagine what his wife and kids are feeling right now. His children can't grow up with their dad. His wife is now a single parent. I genuinely hate Charlie, but I can't imagine how his family is handling this right now. And apparently they witnessed it. The way the blood came out of his neck was genuinely traumatizing. The way his body went limp immediately was horrifying. But anyways, moving on to the D4 V D situation. He's been on tour for like what, a month now? He hasn't been in LA for like a month. And the body hadn't decomposed enough for it to be in that car for so long. The body was in there for three days, and the police haven't even made him a suspect. And plus he had a concert like yesterday, I'm pretty sure. But yeah, moving on to the girl that was stabbed. She was literally minding her business before she got stabbed. And as soon as she got stabbed, everyone was So calm. Like, hello, she needs help. There was literal blood dripping on the floor. I don't have much information on the other situations, but the fact that this is all happened in a week is honestly scary. Like, this month has just started. What's going on

Okay, so today was my first day at an American high school, and oh, my god, I have a lot to say, so buckle up. First of all, to the motherfucker that decided school should start at 7:45 in the morning, fuck you. Say your prayers and count your days, because I am personally going to file a lawsuit against you. Like, I already adjusted to the time zones. I legit thought I was safe. Nope. I'm suddenly expected to brush my teeth before the sun even knows what's going on. Okay, moving on. Let's talk about the cult you guys have labeled school fashion. Why was everyone wearing red and black pajama pants? Was this planned? It was like walking into a Christmas themed asylum. But I'm not even gonna hate, because I am absolutely dragging my host mom to target to get some so I can blend in with the cult members. Anyway, first thing they gave me was my schedule, and then first thing I did was hide in the bathroom, because what the fuck do you mean I'm supposed to actually talk to people? Absolutely not. Homeroom teacher was chill, though. Shout out to Mr. Lincoln for not forcing me to stand up and introduce myself. Fucking legend. Thankfully, my host sister was in most of my classes, so I just stayed with her and her friends. Now, my classes were really easy, like I suspected. So to the people who told me school was gonna Be hard. Yikes. That is, until I had biology fifth period, bro. I did not realize how many science words exist that I don't know in English. They gave me a language helper, like a translator. I felt like a fucking idiot. They also messed up my classes again and put me in French class. What am I supposed to do in there? They said it's gonna take a few weeks before I get my classes switched. But you know what? I actually kind of get it now. I get why you guys hate French, but I don't even think it's the language's fault. I think your teachers just hate their jobs. About lunch. Oh, my god. Lunch was disgusting. Starting to feel like the chicken was not chicken. How are you people not dying from this? Do you just build immunity over the years? Like a vaccine, but edible? Also, why is it so short? 45 minutes. That is not enough. I'm gonna stop here before this turns into a fucking documentary. Tomorrow I'll give you the tea on the people instead of the school itself. Anyways, I'm done yapping, so bye.

My girlfriend's family mocked me in Japanese for an entire meal, then shocked them with one sentence. I've been dating Yuki for six months. When she finally invited me to Sunday dinner with her family, my hands were sweating because this girl meant everything to me and family approval was her world. Just warning you, she said, gripping the steering wheel. They can be protective and they speak Japanese at home, so don't take it personally if they seem cold. I nodded, my stomach in knots. But she didn't know Japanese was my first language. Half Japanese through my mom, but I inherited every single one of my Irish dad's genes. Pale skin, light eyes, the works. People see me and assume white guy. And honestly, sometimes it's been easier to let them. Tanaka House hit me like a warm hug. Keco's cooking filled the air. Multiple generations chatted everywhere. Yuki's mom greeted me with a polite bow and formal smile. Nice to meet you, she said in careful English. The pleasure is mine. Tanakasan. That's when I caught it. The second I turned to her dad, I heard Keiko whisper to Yuki's aunt Kogai, when I got to, when I did, so you, this foreigner won't last long. Game on. For the next hour, I smiled politely while they served me passive aggression, English to my face, Japanese when they thought I couldn't understand and they were brutal me. Te Kogai, Yuki's grandmother said, passing rice. Look at this. Foreigner, so pale and weak looking. Karare washashitsukaina, her uncle muttered. He can't even hold chopsticks properly. No manners. Tommy enjoying the food, Yuki's cousin asked sweet, then whispered, he probably doesn't know what he's eating. I gritted my teeth but stayed quiet. Be polite. Don't cause a scene, Kiko said, refilling my tea. This person is so rude, doesn't even try to learn our customs, the aunt added. He's probably making fun of Japanese culture. Every comment was a small cut, but I kept my mouth shut. Yuki tried including me, switching languages, looking frustrated as conversations kept drifting to rapid Japanese that shut me out. Then her dad talked to Yuki's brother like I was invisible, he said, this is what happens when daughters go to universities. They bring home gaijin who will never understand us. Yuki WA hontoni bakada, the brother replied. Yuki is truly being stupid dating someone who doesn't speak our language. How can there be real love without communication? My jaw clenched. Canno jabun nojise WA munaishi iro keco added, she's wasting her life on someone who can't even talk to her family. My chest burned. I taken insults about my appearance, my manners, my culture. But calling Yuki stupid for loving someone, that crossed every line. Then.

You didn't forget, did you forget? What exactly 15 years ago you said that if we were both single at 30, we'd get married. Wow. I can't believe you still remember. Well, are you ready for the wedding? Because I've been ready to call you mine for forever. Oh, that's so sweet, Alyssa. I love you so much. But wait, you don't even know if I have a girlfriend right now. I know you don't have one. Well, it's actually kind of complicated and I don't think that we can just get married right now. Have to. We made a promise. Come on. We were just dumb 16 year olds. I don't even know what you've been up to in life. Well, you're divorced and I'm divorced. So let's have dinner at least so we can catch up. Okay, that sounds fun. Alright, meet me at 6 at Francesco's Pizza. Oh my god. You still remember that spot? Of course. See you then. I really enjoyed our time together. I can't believe you were serious about the wedding. You know, maybe our younger selves were onto something. Do you remember that night when we promised each other? We were sitting next to each other at the beach. It was so cold that your beautiful body started shivering. So I gave you my jacket and hugged you so hard. Then you whispered in my ears, you'd make a really good wife. And then I said, if we are both single at 30. We should marry each other. I can't believe you remember all that. How could I forget? Things were so much simpler back then. My life is really complicated now after my divorce. Well, maybe we were meant for each other after all. Alyssa, I really like you a lot, but I need some time. Let's make a deal, my love. We will meet each other six months from now, October 25th, at six PM at the same beach we sat at 15 years ago at the same bench. If our love is true, I will see you there. If not, I respect your decision. I won't see any of your text messages until then. But please still keep sending me updates about your life. I love you, Lucia. What do you mean, Alyssa? Wait, Alyssa, it's been a month. I can't stop thinking about our deal. I will keep updating you about my life until we meet. I miss you. Hey, I got a promotion today. I truly did love you and I wish you could know that. But it's too late now. Maybe we were meant for each other, but in the afterlife, Lucia, I didn't die.

My girlfriend said, let's just be friends after two years together. So I treated her exactly like I treat my other friends. With boundaries. Tara and I had been together for two years, living together, for one. We were talking about future plans, her sister's wedding next summer, where I was supposed to be her plus one. Then on a random Thursday evening, she sat me down for the talk. I love you, but I'm not in love with you anymore. She. I think we should transition to being friends. We get along so well, have the same friend group. We'd make amazing friends. But not amazing partners. Here's what killed me. She said all this while already having packed a bag. Her friend Marissa was picking her up in an hour. She planned this whole thing down to having somewhere to stay, already got an exit strategy. I said, we're adults. We're friends. We can make this work. I sat there processing. Two years living together, talking about kids someday. Now she wants to be buddies? Okay. I said, yeah, let's be friends. She actually smiled, relieved, like I just agreed to her perfect plan where she gets to dump me but keep all the benefits of having me in her life. The next morning, I did exactly what Tara asked. Treated her like a friend. That's when I Learned she had a very different definition of friendship than I did. First text came at 7:00am. Could you drop Off my work laptop? Sure. I'll leave it at the front desk of your office Monday. Can't you bring it by Marissa's? I need it for the weekend. I've got plans. Monday works better. She didn't like that.
